Reviews.title: Excellent performance for its class, runs toasty however.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2019
Reviews.text:
This low-midrange semi-compact card is a nice little addition to the budget series of graphics cards, especially on Nvidia's side. It outperforms it's competitors and some of the Nvidia vanilla cards without demanding a new power supply, assuming you have a 400W or above already. Unlike the original 1650 and lower models, this requires a 6-pin PCIe connector, which isn't asking much considering it being just a bit above the limit where you wouldn't need one, this card does however run hot, was nearing 80C on Ultra playing Dead By Daylight (thanks again to Asus for the free game back in 2016 from my 950 mini purchase), I did not pay attention to the other settings, just switched to Ultra and started playing, it's not perfect, however, even on ultra I was still getting noticeably better performance than my now broken Zotac 1050 Ti that was struggling on medium, that shows the huge loop in performance just within the next line of cards and having the OC addition of an already upgraded card. Though, Nvidia made their lineup rather confusing and a bit frustrating for some this time around, especially for those who have already chosen the vanilla 1650 which happens to be the same price at the moment, I appreciate their effort into making a card (from all manufacturers) that despite it's inferior specs to some of the competition, can still outperform some of those cards, whether all the time or at some point in a game, depending on the model of course, and without the need to upgrade to more power, sizable form-factors, and even specs, which shows that even that doesn't tell the whole deal on performance. The only real downside about this I can say is it seems a little fragile with what looks to be thinner PCB, shroud, and backplate, and it runs very hot, especially boosted. What I do like about the card is Asus's effort into thinking about other factors in design like dust-resistance and fan bearings. I've had 3 cards fail because the bearings would wear out within a year or two and start grinding without even many hours into the games, or at least many being the "typical" gamer average, I'm talking failure within about 5 hours of playing a demanding game after just doing minor graphical tasks on every other instance for the span of 1-2 years. After the card nears 80, it does downclock at some point so that it could get back into the mid-70s without a huge performance loss but temperature is certainly its weak point; the heatsink and overall heat dissipation setup is rather small as well, so that doesn't help. After having 3 cards fail, longevity has been my main concern; these little cards just seem to give out rather early. I'm hoping the new bearings, IP5X dust-resistance, and technology behind the card will help its lifespan, and that the heat won't become an issue for the card itself, performance, and rest of my components. With a 1850+Mhz clock boost, at its size, it's power requirements, and it's performance, this thing is a beast in a compact package, not just with what it can do but the thought behind the specs and technology of the card and its components as well. It's nice to see a company for once make a positive change, and not release the same exact design for a basic card despite the lineup difference. Hopefully other companies can take note and start using something like ball bearings for their fans and take into account little issues vulnerable components can face and put more thought into their cards, however, with this Asus, temperature is the only real concerning problem that I would say maybe they haven't put much thought into as far as that regard, maybe all out performance was their focus, or maybe didn't think it would be an issue? Either way, this is a nice card, I chose this version over the Zotac mainly because of the bearings and tech behind it, also it was only $5 more and is factory OC'd. After 3 bad Zotac experiences, I think my choice was justified.

Pros:

*Excellent performance for its class and size.

*Fairly compact single fan design with minor fitting issues I ran into with the backplate needing to budge/be pulled hard and held toward the screw holes to put the screws in.

*Extra thought into the design of some of the most important components

*Does look nice imo with the "ASUS Geforce GTX" font on the side while viewing inside the case.

Cons:

*Runs hot with small heat dissipation setup and not much that can be done to resolve the issue

*Could have looked a little nicer in terms of aesthetics but with something like this already, that's just nitpicking, though I'm sure it could have been done.

*Packaging might have been missing stuff, or ditched GPU Tweak II CD but it might have been done intentionally on this model. Box is rather barebones once you lift the cardboard holding the card, so I feel it could have been downsized to save on materials.

Mix:

*build quality seems just average, or less than what I'd like it to be, just a standard card made to do one job, but feels a little fragile with what seems to be thinner parts and some low-quality feeling materials. Hard to tell its durability and strength. The PCB and backplate seem a little thinner than usual or what I'm used to, and the plastic shroud just feels lightweight/cheap and/or thin of itself, not sure about the actual quality of all the components though. Could just be using not necessarily lower-grade but different materials. Who knows? Could end up being better, at least I hope.

UPDATE: 3/23/21. ASUS, please keep using ball-bearing fans and I'll buy your cards every single time, since no other company seems to think about fan design and longevity, my last 3-4 cards died between 1 and 3 years from fan-failure because the sleeve bearings would go bad and start grinding from drastic temperature changes after playing some demanding games.

Reviews.title: Perked up my old Lenovo
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
Reviews.text: I purchased this to replace the factory installed GT730 on my Lenovo Ideacentre 710-25ISH I bought from Best Buy six or so years ago. I tried streaming Train Simulator 2020 on Twitch and a friend commented that the capture was laggy. I had noticed that my PC would take a hit on frames in high traffic areas, and could only play on medium detail settings at best. I purchased an EVGA 750 G5 Gold-Series modular power supply at the same time as the 1650 to ensure I had more than enough juice for the new GPU before installation. The GPU was larger than I expected but still left plenty of room in the case. I liked the black with white racing stripes design but as I don't have a clear case it will (hopefully) be a long time before I see it again. The GPU plugged right into the PCI slot and snugged right in to the backing plate once it was secured. This GPU did require me to remove a second backing plate in order for it to fit properly, my old 730 only took up the one. This GPU also requires a 4-pin plug connection from the PSU to power it; it will not receive power solely from the PCI slot. I haven't had enough time in Train Simulator to take actual FPS readings, but can tell you the game now runs at its highest detail settings like butter. Zero lag, very smooth, and the added detail is like night and day. This is a great GPU that offers a budget upgrade without hogging up all the space in a tower and demanding a ton of power.

Reviews.title: So far, the best value entry level gaming PLUS streaming.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this thinking I might be able to stream 1080p 60fps but BEWARE there will be a LOT of stutters, duplicated frames during the stream/recording. I do either 900p or 720p for smooth streaming and gaming. Make sure to run OBS as administrator. If you're looking to play and stream at the same time and you don't have a lot of money to spend, this card is a go.

Here are my thoughts. I'm pretty sure you've watched reviews on Youtube but here goes anyways. If you haven't, though, you should.
Noise: The fans only ramp up during streaming and gaming where the GPU has to work extra hard, otherwise, barely audible if you have a completely quiet room. If you have either speakers or normal headphones, you won't be able to hear the noise at all.

Performance: You really get what you pay for. You can play triple A games at low or medium settings at 1080p 60fps EASILY. This card doesn't even sweat. As long as you don't ask for too much, you'll be satisfied for sure.

Thermals: Averages around 70-75 degree Celsius under full load. Peaks at 75 degrees when you play demanding games for hours, it doesn't go above that at all if you don't overclock it. It's already factory overclocked and still has some room for overclocking.

Overall, this card is one of the best, if not THE best entry level graphics card, and you add streaming to that value. You can't really go wrong with this card. It won't disappoint you. You might think it's bad because of the bad reputation that the normal 1650 has, but this card is on another level. For $20 more bucks, you get 40% more performance than the normal GTX 1650, the new NVENC encoding with Turing architecture for streaming, and in this card's case, overclocked, quiet and excellent cooling.

Reviews.title: Pretty loud fans, but great budget performance.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
Reviews.text:
Please keep in mind I purchased this card at $180. I would recommend against paying for the Winter 2020 price of this card, as the performance is definitely not worth the current price.

I may have got an excellent copy, but this card can sit at 2GHz overclock pretty happily. Many games can run at 1080 60fps at high or ultra, but you do tend to see the limitations of 4GB VRAM. For workstation usage, having the new NVENC encoder is great for working in Premiere, but again more VRAM would be nice. I don't run many AAA titles but expect to run them around medium-high, which for me is definitely acceptable.

In terms of the actual TUF 1650S, while I did look for a dual fan for better noise, this card is still pretty loud. It gets annoying when you need to restart your computer often. I believe it isn't the actual air moving, but the fans themselves, as running older cards with different fan designs are much quieter. If you care about the noise output, look for a better fan design.

Reviews.title: replaced a dead Radeon RX580
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
I had purchased this GPU for a PC build I was working on, however shortly after it arrived an RX580 card went bad on my son's PC. So I ended up dropping this one in and it was a great swap. Both this and the 580 are in the same ballpark in terms of performance but this card basically does just about everything a tiny bit better. So my son tends to play fortnite, destiny 2, Doom, Doom Eternal, and Valorant at 1440p, all run just a little better on the GTX 1650 Super than they did with the RX580.

I have read, and believe that in terms of bang for your buck there is no better card to get than a GTX1650 Super. It's a great CPU to start out with, and you can play all the games you want while you save your pennies for a card that will get you 4k@120Hz.

Recommended, great building block for a gaming PC.

Reviews.title: A very good upgrade
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
Reviews.text:
I have an older Dell Optiplex 990 MT and after going to Windows 10 I found the video card to be lacking. I had enough CPU power, fast memory, a SSD and even upgraded the power supply to a 600 Watt version but the video....

After looking at the reviews and seeing what I do, streaming video and photo work, I found this video card to all that and more. The card just fit inside my Dell case and the new PS had the 6 pin power connector for the GPU and I was all set.

It does not come with drivers so you need to get them off the ASUS site and it's easy to find and install. 15 minutes later I was up and running. The fans are quiet and the dashboard program to adjust the features of the GPU are easy to use and navigate. At ~$160 bucks it a good value. I appreciated the HDMI, Display Port and DVI outputs on the back. I used two of them for my dual display and this card powers both easily.

Reviews.title: A solid budget card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
Reviews.text: The Asus GeForce GTX 1650 Super is a solid budget/ entry level card. It is VERY quiet. I can't here it at all in my tower. It has GDDR6 that is very fast and gives this card it's go juice. It's fairly compact in length but be careful that you have enough space between your pcie slots because this card is wider than a standard double width card. I found out the hard way. It's a decent value if you are playing at 1080p anything higher and you will need more muscle. I REALLY DISLIKE the fact that the card has only 4gb of ram. I feel it should come with six gb of ram. 4gb makes it feel cheap in a bad way. Prices of video cards has gotten really stupidly high over the last few years so I'm kind of soured on both Nvidia and AMD as I feel they are both price gouging customers based on cost vs actual performance of ALL video cards. I hope Intel will be able to compete in a couple of years and drive these prices back down to reasonable levels.

Reviews.title: Works, plays games and stuff
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2022
Reviews.text: Expensive for what it is but probably the best value at the time. I suggest waiting till prices come down. I was impatient.

Reviews.title: Nice and powerful, but loud!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
Reviews.text:
I am very much impressed at the power this graphics card pumped out! Really improved my PC's graphics performance x2 at least!

I purchased when price was only $181.

Only issue is it gets very noisy when I play ANY* graphics intensive games. Two fans cranking! But frame rate is good otherwise. Oh, and the other issue I had was with the installation, Unless you fit it in there perfect, the fan will hit the plastic housing and make a hellacious noise like it will break the fans blade! Be mindful if you purchase and install yourself!
Great budget card otherwise though! I absolutely love it!

Reviews.title: Works great! but...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2020
Reviews.text: I bought this product a while ago and decided it was about time to make a review on it. This GPU runs great and I've had no problems running AAA games at pretty high quality and still getting above 50fps. Something that sort of threw me off when I first got this is that it's not the same make as the one in the photograph, and on the box. I'm not sure if it makes a difference, but mine only comes with 1 cooling fan, and the product was advertised as having 2. I'm still kind of pissed off by this, however I am not upset by the results this GPU gives me. If I had gotten the GPU I'd expected, this review would certainly be 5 stars.

Reviews.title: Works perfectly in my Dell XPS 8700 after some upgrades
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought a new game (Snowrunner) and found that my older Dell XPS 8700 PC (i7 3.4 Gen-4) was not in the minimum specs for the game.

With this 1660 Super I needed to upgrade the power supply in my PC to a new 620w version (SeaSonic S12II) that fit perfectly in the case with no modifications needed. I then added two sticks of Corsair memory for a total of 24GB. I then install two 90mm Noctura fans in the case (one on the back and one in the front (no case mod required)). The back fan is connected to power from the power supply and the front fan is controlled by the motherboard. I then took two slot blanks out of the back by the 1660 to move a little more air. My CPU still has the original Intel CPU cooler on it but that will be upgraded eventually. The PC idles at 32c - 37c and games at around 69c - 75c.

None-the-less the game looks beautiful with the new GTX 1660 Super video card and has so far been completely glitch free. I do not have a 4k monitor so I'm not taxing the card but in HD with a lot of the game video settings maxed it has been doing very well. This should get me another year or two out of this old PC until it's time to build one.

Reviews.title: Good budget card for the money
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
Reviews.text:
Review for PNY GeForce GTX 1660 Super 6GB XLR8 Gaming Overclocked Edition Single Fan:

This card is great choice for 1080p Gaming. It will play most game titles at 1080p high or ultra settings at or over 60fps. I bought this card to replace my old RX-580 because it died out on me. This card was about a 20-40 percent increase in performance over my old card depending on what game titles were being used. This card is being used with my 144hz monitor and keeps up with it for most game titles. This card has very good low power consumption. Under full load usage the temps for the card stay between 60-70 degrees while gaming for a few hours and it hasn't gone over 70 degrees while gaming as well. If you are looking for a 2k resolution budget card for over 60fps with high or ultra settings, this card can run at 2k decently. It can game at 2k resolution at medium to high settings for 60 fps with graphic settings tweaked in game but this card's sweet spot is definitely for 1080p gaming. The only gripe I have with this card is that it is loud under load. Its not overwhelming loud but but at full load you can here the fan spin up and it is noticeable. Overall I think its a solid choice for 1080p gaming.

Reviews.title: It did not come in even a black colored box.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2022
Reviews.text: I read some of the reviews before I purchased, so I kinda knew it wouldn't come in a wrapped retail box. However, mine came in a white box with just a piece of bubble wrap around it. It didn't even come with PNY logo printed black color box. When I took the video card freshly out of the box, I could see a lot of dusts on the card and also on the fan. I can definitely tell this has been used for sometime. I tested it and luckily it works. I don't know if I need to return it.

Reviews.title: Great card, purchased a year ago foR $264. Wouldn't buy at this price.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2022
Reviews.text:
Have had this card for over a year no with no issues what so ever, it does not collect a a lot of dust, then again, I clean my PC monthly. Great small card, would not buy it for $600 right now although.

Runs Apex other games like that comfortably around 90-110 frames. Get around 60-80 for triple A titles like Red dead.

Temps vary from 40c to 70c max that I have seen.

Reviews.title: Good card, just loud
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
Reviews.text:
Good-
I can run RE2, The Hunter, GTA 5, at 1080p on ultra/very high no issue which is what I was looking for.

If you want to upgrade from your old card and don’t care about 4k ultra 144hz RTX I think this card is what you’re looking for

Form factor is great. I wanted something small for my micro build and it fits a lot better than I expected

The bad-

The only thing that really bothers me is the single fan. You can tell that it is struggling to keep it cool. When it ramps up you’ll definitely know it. Between about 65-70C it gets a little louder and beyond that it sounds like the fan is rubbing or rattling. More effort should’ve really been put in that because it can get annoying.

Reviews.title: This is a great card for multiple 1080p monitors!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
Reviews.text:
I've had this card for a while now. I've been running it with Linux. The card works great!!!

This card does not get super hot when running under a heavy load. Stays around 73 degrees Celsius or less. I run a graphically intensive MMO game on 2x 1080p screens with the graphics quality maxed off this card and it works great.

This card will run 4K, but you probably want a better card if you are gaming in 4K. If you are not running 4K, you probably don't really need a better card than this one!

If you are wanting to mine digital currency, this is not the right card to get! This card will mine, but you are not going to make much money using this card.

Reviews.title: Works great with COD - Warzone. Outputs 4k 60hz for my HTPC
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
Upgrading from a Quadro K2000 to this GTX 1660 Super made a HUGE difference in frame rates, and latency when playing COD-Warzone. I could actually play now, the old card lagged so badly I couldn't play effectively at all.
GPU response time dropped from 30ms to 3ms, Latency dropped from 170-300ms to 5-25ms over a 300Mbps internet connection.
Unit is silent unless under heavy load, and then I don't tend to notice, as it's STILL fairly quiet. Even with the two fans on this model.
Using it in a Dell Precision T3610 HTPC (685W PS), driving a 4k 60" TV.
Using the HDMI-output with and HDMI 2.0 cable is putting out 4k / 60hz.
Rock solid with latest drivers from nVidia website.
Wish the price was a little less, but it's inline with everybody else. Luckily I had a couple Amazon gift cards to drop the total for me.

Reviews.title: No Power Adapter Cable
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2022
Reviews.text: This card needs an 8 pin PCIE express power connection but DOES NOT come with a SATA power adapter cable.

Reviews.title: Great little card for overclocking, if you have the case fans to support it.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
Reviews.text: I absolutely love this card, it runs amazing in games. Supporting my 144hz monitor beautifully. I have it paired with an i5 9600k and 16gb of ram. I'm running a fairly decent overclock on the card and I'm seeing performance up there with a GTX 1070 easy. The only thing I notice, obviously, is the card does get warm under long periods of load. Other than that the card if very fast, very good value if purchased for under $300, and I would 100% recommend it to someone looking for a budget card that'll last them a good while.

Reviews.title: keeps up with most new games wit settings turned down, BEAST for old-ish games
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2021
Reviews.text: with a little tinkering in msi afturburner you can run games like cyberpunk at 1440p high-ish(most things on high with a few exceptions such as clouds and reflections) but where this shines is playing anything pre2019 at 4k 60 on ultra settings. honestly impressed with this little thing. and its QUIET at full tilt. with afturburner i was able to get an oc of 1995mhz and it would boot to 2010mhz when it really needed to. and the memory will oc to 7950mhz(base :7000mhz oc: +950mhz) and still be stable. great card

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on July 25, 2022
Reviews.text: Original card should comes with ARGB cable in the box, while there is nothing besides the card when arrived, should mention that in the description at least. Also, I've did some benchmark and stress testing on the card, seems that the score is within the lower range of typical 6600XT cards, not sure if it is because of 'renewed' or because of the AIB manufacturer. Anyway, without the original warranty, I don't think it is the best option to get this especially longevity is what you are looking for when selecting graphic cards, not to mention that the price of GPU is tanking.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on August 5, 2022
Reviews.text:
For $290 I received a working 6600xt. This card comes with no manufacturer warranty, no peripherals, simply a box with a packaged card in it. The story of why it is classified as "renewed" can mean many things other than the card being new. The price reflects this and should be considered when purchasing. I am satisfied with the purchase and understand the risk involved with a renewed card- albeit you do have 30 day return window with Amazon.

The 5star is simply because the card works and for the performance it offers at the price I paid. Card was clean too, no scratches or really signs that it was used before.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on August 31, 2022
Reviews.text: Received card, slight bit of dust within cooling fins, but nearly brand new looking at it. Installed to replace my RX580, no signal no matter what I tried, LEDs on card lit up, no fan action, no output on any display port. Not sure what testing these get when they are headed out the door but thankful for the Amazon return policy. Not sure if I would take my chance on another one of these to be honest.

data.description: The GeForce GTX 1660 SUPER is up to 20% faster than the original GTX 1660 and up to 1.5X faster than the previous-generation GTX 1060 6GB. MEIRIYFA Multifunctional video card bracket ,Designed for a wide range of graphics cards and boards.
Universal VGA Graphics Card Holder for Computer Cases.

data.description: NVIDIA Quadro 5000 professional graphics board, 2. 5 GB GDDR5 GPU Memory, 352 CUDA Cores, PCI Express 2. 0 x16 system interface, 2x DP 1. 2 connectors, 1x DVI-I DL connector, full height, dual slot, 152 W max power consumption.

Reviews.title: a bit dodgy
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2021
Reviews.text:
on first startup the fan rubs on the surrounding shroud, takes surrounding shroud off... ok fixed.

even though it has 2x DP 1. 2 connectors you can only really use one at a time.

yes it supports up to 2560x1600 on 2x screens thru the DP chaining feature but that is really the monitor just passing thru the signal. so if you think you can just run 2x DP cables one to each in a pair of monitors your not going to get an extended desktop.

you can however run one DP cable and one DVI cable and get an extended desktop on 2x screens @ 2560x1600

it maybe possible to run 2x DP cables and get an extended desktop but finding support for this card is impossible. there might have been special drivers at one time but that seems to be lost in the mists of the past.

all in all... it's a marginally ok experience. Resolve does run ok'ish just pretty slow but this was not a surprise. Unless you have a very specific use case don't waste your money on this card, I did... thinking I was going to get maybe a useable setup.

Reviews.title: Excellent customer service
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2011
Reviews.text:
The car is what you could expect from the Quadro range, an excellent piece of hardware with very good performances with professional applications. If you are only after casual 3D modeling or for gaming, it is better (less expensive) to look for a GTX 580, however for professional use this is an outstanding product.

I also give 5 star because of the Amazon service : it happened to me that a wrong board was sent the first time : I was obviously disappointed and sent a claim to Amazon. To my amazement, in less than 24 hours they acknowledged it and sent over a new board (on December 24th) without asking a single question. I can honestly say I never experienced an aftersales service like this.

Reviews.title: Replacement for HP Z800 workstation original NVIDIA Quadro 5000 card for video editing
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2017
Reviews.text: I bought a refurbished HP Z800 for the primary purpose of video editing using Adobe Premier CC. 48 GB DDR3 2x Intel Xeon Six Core E5645 2.4 GHz. My (original) NVIDIA Quadro 5000 video card failed after a couple of years. Bought two of these identical replacement cards (they work together) to increase video file rendering and exporting efficiency. Enables the use of Adobe Mercury Playback Engine GPU Acceleration (CUDA). Noticeable difference in performance using two. Easy installation on the modular Z800.

Reviews.title: Problematic
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2012
Reviews.text:
I got this item for a workstation. However it overheated and crashed the machine in the initials.
I sent it back to PNY which I must say had very good customer service.
However when I received the replacement it did not operate AutoCAD with the performance I got from a generic 3d fx gaming card.

From what i gathered it was due to the shear size of our drawing and data on it that it operated rather laggy as it tried to regenerate the drawing accurately for any zoom, pan or rotation.
We eventually went back to the original gaming graphics card which operated much more smoothly.

Reviews.title: Great Video Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2017
Reviews.text:
I recently replaced another brand video card, which was recommended by a college professor, and the difference is amassing.
Using all the same components that I was using with the other brand video card, I can now see individual hairs and count blades
of grass!

Especially for some customers who has systems sensitive to the electromagnetic environment, that is why we designed this GPU support without any megnet. and if you wanna the one with magnet, please kindly search "glotrends" for more options.

Reviews.title: Just works.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2022
Reviews.text: For less than $10 you can't go wrong. Have had this in my system for about a year. Got a Chungus of GPU(EVGA 3080tiFTW) and had never experienced GPU sag. Needed something fast and cheap and this fit the bill. It has a nice anthracite powder coating, I believe you can get it in other colors, but this one fit my build the best. I actually positioned mine as close to my motherboard as I could, and almost between the GPU and mobo and you can only see it if your right up at the glass. It still looked decent when positioned directly in the middle of the card, but it got in the way of my tubing.

Reviews.title: Simple and it works as others have said
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
Reviews.text: To long for my need now that I got it, but price is right. I will just saw it down to the right size (and fit a black rubber cap to the top to support the end of the GPU). Need only about a 2-1/3" lift from the case floor to the GPU to support the GPU - it's a RX6700XT, and d*mn near 12-1/2 inches+ long, and MOST brackets are too short (ones that are horizontal from the rear case GPU mount screws), and this, and similar (vertical supports) are generally far to high. I thought this one had two sections that screwed in and little screwed top piece, and I was only going to use one of the 2 sections, but I think I just selected the wrong one when I was looking for the (about)$10 price ones - which is all these should cost at most ! It'll work. Picture of inside of my Lian Li Snow Mini with the Power Color RT 6700 XT at the bottom and now being supported by this bracket and about 4 inches of the support rod above the top of the GPU. Plan to just hacksaw it off, and repaint or put a cap or something on the top. All red as yo can see with thew RGB thinggies.

Reviews.title: Works in a pinch

Reviews.title: The locking screw to hold the video card up doesnt even lock
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2021
Reviews.text: Strangest thing ever, the screw that screws into the pole to lock the holding plate that fits under the video card to hold it in place. Has a stopped on it that you screw it in its exactly flush with the inside of the pole so it doesnt even reach the pole and im wondering how youre supposed to lock it in place. If you put pressure on it where the plate is at an angle it sort of locks and wont slide but it still is a very strange design decision to make it this way. I know it was a conscious decision to make it this way though because theres a circular disc around it to keep the screw from going any further. But WHY???? So weird. I plan to get another screw to go into it so i can lock the plate in place, otherwise the pole and base are sturdy as well as the plate. Just the locking screw is just more like a handle on the outside of the plate than something that actually locks it. Really weird. So thats why i gave it such a low reveiw score its kind of useless since you cant lock it really. Weird....

data.label: XFX RX 5700 XT Raw II 8GB GDDR6 1905MHz 3xDP HDMI PCI Express 4.0 Graphics Card RX-57XT8OFF6
data.description: Bend the rules great gaming experiences are created by bending the rules. The AMD Radeon RX 5700 Series GPUs are powered by the all new RDNA architecture and are designed from the ground up for exceptional 1440P performance, exceptional power-efficiency for high-fidelity gaming. Equipped with the latest 8GB of GDDR6 high-speed memory and PCI Express 4.0 support, delivering twice the bandwidth. Specifications: Bus type: PCI-E 4.0, base clock: 1605MHz, game clock: 1755MHz, boost clock: Up to 1905MHz, stream processors: 2560, memory bus: 256 bit, memory clock: 14 Gbps, memory size: 8 GB, memory type: GDDR6, card profile: 2.9 slot, thermal solution: DD Fansink. Features - Display Port ready DisplayPort 1.4 HDR, HDMI ready 2.0b.

Reviews.title: Great Card, Terrible Drivers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020
Reviews.text:
AMD has really hit a great sweet spot here with the 5XXX line of cards, specifically the 5700XT. This card benchmarks similar or better performance than a nVidia 2070 Super, at a much lower price! That's always been AMD's A game, best bang for the buck, and they've hit that spot again.

Now specifically about this card. I was leary about spending less on a card when the "bigger name" brands are $30-$100 more, but I've had XFX cards in the past and they've worked just fine, so I gave this one a shot.

Out of the box, this card was MUCH larger than I expected. I had to move around SATA ports just to get it to fit. I expected it to be around the size of my RX480, but I way underestimated that! So know going in you need to make sure your motherboard layout isn't going to be effected by this card's size. It's much wider and longer than any previous AMD card I've seen.

Now, as for the performance. On boot, everything seemed great. I've always had problems with AMD's drivers, they're notorious for having buggy, crashing driver releases. I've always had multiple system crashes when doing clean installs of AMD's graphics drivers in the past. But doing a complete clean driver install worked flawlessly, no crashes on the driver install. Huge pleasant surprise!

Then I tried playing some games to start testing the performance. That's where I started to run into serious problems. Every game I tried to play, my computer would hard lock. The GPU driver was crashing. Obviously that's incredibly frustrating for a brand new high end graphics card. I tried changing game settings, both in regular gaming and VR, and nothing changed. Drivers would crash every time after getting into the game (though the menus would load fine).
Before considering an RMA, I looked into the issue to see how many others were having these problems, and it appears to be a very large number of people. After a couple of hours of digging, I discovered the issue was because the graphics card is overlooked out of the box WAY over stock, and even higher than the highest advertised overclocked cards. This is why it was crashing. This is a serious oversight from a firmware/driver standpoint. The default settings should never be overclocked. The main problem comes from the voltage is set at 1.2mV by default, and the card can't handle that much voltage. You have to undervolt the card, in my case to 0.99mV in order to get the card to run on stock settings.
That in itself is a simple enough fix, except that you can't force the card to actually run at those settings by default, you have to use software to change those settings on system startup. And that's where another issue came up. AMD's software for overclocking (or in this case underclocking) their hardware, Wattman, would not save these new settings on startup no matter what I tried. Every boot, even with the software running on startup and the profile saved as default, the card would start with the original default settings. This would be incredibly frustrating to have to manually change the graphics settings on every reboot/crash.
So rather than use AMD's software, I had to resort to using other software to manage the settings. In this case MSI AfterBurner. MSI's software has worked flawlessly for years, but it does have issues with compatibility with VR (specifically Oculus), so do keep that in mind if you do a lot of VR gaming.
The next issue that I ran into is that apparently AMD's FreeSync does NOT work with this card, at least on the current drivers. So that also had to be disabled, which is incredibly disappointing, but would certainly have to be fixed at some point. So I'm waiting for further driver updates to hopefully be able to turn that back on.

After finally getting all of that sorted out, it was finally time to test some games! This thing is an absolute beast for gaming. A massive upgrade from my RX480! I play in 2k resolution, and the RX480 (even if overclocked) would struggle to keep even 30 FPS in some demanding games on high/ultra settings, but not this! I can max out all graphics settings and play at 2k resolution and keep over 60 FPS on every game I've tried! The only notable exception being Star Citizen, but being an Alpha it's terribly poorly optimized, and even the highest end systems struggle to keep 60 FPS everywhere. But I do keep a stable 45 FPS average, which is fantastic. Though most games are able to sustain 144 FPS as well, for an incredible gaming experience! Specially Elite Dangerous stays at 144 FPS even in large battles!

I want to knock more stars off this card just for all the frustration I went through just to get it to even work, but since then I haven't had a single issue with the card. It runs perfectly now! So just go into getting this card (and I would assume other 5700XT boards may have this same issue) knowing that you're going to have to do some tweaks before you'll be able to use it. AMD has the absolute worst driver support, it's downright dreadful. But they've always been this way. If their software team could actually catch up to their hardware team, they'd probably be killing nVidia on all fronts. They just can't.

So overall, I definitely recommend this card for an upgrade. It was a huge upgrade for me and it's nice to have great gaming performance again. Just know you're going to likely have issues until they sort all of this out!

Reviews.title: 2022 AMD Updated Drivers and Fixed Black Screen Issues Card is Amazing
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
This card at launch when I purchased it was plagued with the same video card driver issues AMD has become notorious for in the community. However, now that years have passed since this card's release and AMD has sunk more money into optimizing their video cards for gaming, especially the new 6000 series cards, the result is that latest Adrenalin Software driver update in 2022 has this card screaming in games I play without stability issues I used to have.

The driver updates have also allowed me to fully use the various functions this card has like Radeon sharpening or input lag reduction etc. with no performance cost at all! Keep in mind that all of these improvements whilst still drawing the same power and without overclocking. That's right, stock speed baby. AMD has come through to finally fix these issues and I can recommend this card in July 2022 now that card prices are at or below MSRP and well worth it with current driver editions. Nice AMD!

Reviews.title: BIg card. Bit loud out of box. Can be tempered.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
Reviews.text:
I think this is really worth 4.5 stars, but I don't want to short-change it.

This card is pretty great given that it's usually the more budget-conscious of 5700XT. Which is not to say "it works fine BUT..." We've skipped some RGB but have a metal backplate and metal accents on a very solid-feeling shroud. Personally I don't care what the shroud feels like - I'm not going to really hold the thing. Make it look nice and call it a day. But the metal brackets and plates don't seem to hurt anything. An aggressive-looking shroud too, but not to a degree that it becomes cringey.

It's easy to lose reference on size in GPU cards especially when looking at dual-fan designs, and this one is quite large. It has a two-slot interface on the output-end of the card but it has a substantial radiator and does take up three slots worth of space over the motherboard. I had to give up wifi for this. mATX builders take not that you will only really be left with one slot available and miniITX that you may not fit into a tight case.

The temperatures and fan noise out of the box are the biggest concern here. AMD temperature reporting maybe looks worse than it is, but that isn't to say this card is fairly hot and loud as received due the the factory overclock/overvolt and aggressive fan curves. There is a bios switch to enable a more basic bios with less aggressive fan curves, but while it's easy, it's not going to be the best method of dealing with these issues. Better to use AMD's own Wattman from the Radeon drivers that you'll install anyways and use that to undervolt and tune some clock speeds. There's a very good chance that this will drop your temps enough and keep your fans from running so high. You could further tweak the fan curves to tune the speeds. I know this seems like a lot of overhead and it could encourage you to look elsewhere, but honestly it's not bad and something you should do for any 5700XT. So it's worth doing regardless.

Make sure you have a good power supply, though. Recommended is a 600 W but you'll need both an 8-pin and a 6-pin power. There are adapters included and I won't say they won't work, but conventional wisdom is that you really should use those as a permanent solution. Can't say I've ever heard of it really causing a problem, though.

Overall, I'm happy to have this as it has everything I need and it's very light on the gimmicks. I've got Destiny 2 running at 1440p and highest settings (except lighter AA and no motion blur) around 130-150 fps. A smallish but significant upgrade from my GTX 1080. I really think the value here is outstanding.

Reviews.title: Best Bang For Bucks Secret!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2019
Reviews.text:
I did take a huge risk with this one, as upon ordering I saw a youtube video that says this card ran Hot and Loud! However, for those of you on the fence with this card, it is the lowest priced card right now of the 5700 XT. I say get it. Yes it does run hot and loud at stock settings! But I noticed that this card was Overclocked and overvolted from the factory! If you change the speed to the stock rated 1905 mhz, adjust the max voltage to .999 mv using globalwattman (AMD's provided driver) and adjust the fan curve accordingly, to keep the fan at or under 50%. The card stays cool at 67 degrees C all day and very quiet as it never gets hot enough for the fan to kick in at even 50% even at full load playing Red Dead 2 on Max Ultra Settings, with get this, NO NOTICEABLE DROP IN PERFORMANCE OR STABILITY AT THE LOWER VOLTAGE!! At this price point, it is a steal, anyone that says otherwise has very little knowledge with how AMD are notorious for overvolting their cards and how these cards were designed to be efficient. or they were probably paid by Nvidia.

I was going to return this card and get the Red Devil, but with the adjusted settings, this card is good to go and is a steal at this price, as it outperforms the 1080 Ti and matches the performance of the RTX 2070 Super, albeit sans Ray Tracing. Get it MNOW!! Best purchase of my life.

And if you're getting this card to play Red Dead 2, use the Vulkan API, it's really what this card was made for! It ran that game buttery smooth, no frame drops, no artifacts, no stutters! Wow! Coming from AMD!!? Seriously! Did not expect this!! And this is a Mid-Tiered card and is already competing with the Flagships!? Just wait until AMD gets serious and decide to bring out the big boys. One thing is I would buy many shares of AMD stocks now! The future is looking very good for them.

Reviews.title: Might have to tighten screws
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2020
Reviews.text:
So I just updated my review because I was having issues but now this card is working fine on stock settings. So first I got the card and it ran hot and got plenty of crashes in games stutter etc and it was due to two things. First I bought a ryzen 1600 af and 3600mhz memory and while it worked games would crash turned it down to 3200mhz. Then this video card I ran hot super hot and it was because the screws were loose on the backplate called support and they told me to tighten them after that I game flawless no issues. (also they said not too tight maybe one full turn or half I went 1.5 turns super tight and no issues. Now last the fan curve on these is pretty low but you can turn it up if needed and I would say only if your pushing this to 4k 60fps may you need to do that but 1440p is the sweet spot.

Also since i changed to these dark flash rgb fans this pc is super quiet and I never hear this card nor does it run hot stays at around 65-72, a lot of people are looking at junction temp which something new amd started showing it means that is the hottest point of the card but 100 or less is fine. If your getting a hot and loud card try to tighten the screws but i love this build and card I do wish it had more lights but its solid

Reviews.title: XFX Rx 5700XT Raw II
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
Reviews.text:
If you are struggling to choose between this graphics card and the 2070 Super, stop searching and looking up FPS comparison. This is the best bang for your buck. Absolute beast for 1080p gaming and handles 1440p with ease. As for the driver issues that many people have complained about, they have been fixed and the new 20.4.1 drivers have resolved all issues. However, for some reason the card I received was overclocked out of the box. After researching, I found many people had experienced the same scenario. This was causing all my games to crash, and I couldn’t figure out why. I never suspected it was due to overclocking since I had never touched these settings(I’m a novice when it comes to performance tweaking). After many hours of headaches, driver updates, google searches, installs, and uninstalls. I realized that my base core-clock was at 2124.... a ridiculous overlock that would struggle even with the best cooling systems in the market. After down-clocking, I have not had any complaints, the card is fabulous. So to summarize, when you receive this card make sure it’s running at the base core clock advertised on amazon or manufacturer website.
Pros
-No coil whine
-Best performance for the price among 5700xt line PERIOD
-Can handle any game at 1440p
Cons
-Raw? More like cooked, can get hot. Usually hovers at 80
-Loud
-Beware of the out of box overclock

Reviews.title: For those Worried About Temperatures
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2020
Reviews.text:
Now, seeing other reviews and the few scarce review videos on other websites reviewing this, I was cautious to buy this but went ahead to do so because of the relative small price. I was not disappointed, while I have a ASUS Full Tower case, the temperatures of the RAW II never exceed 60 C when the fan percentage is set around 60, even on Red Dead Redemption 2, on mostly high-ultra settings, and this is playing for an hour straight, with bad cable management in the case, and the down facing fans only inches away from the PSU.

Needless to say, there are no flashy RGBs nor are they needed, there are two small LEDs that turn red or blue to indicate if the PCIe Power is working however, the build of the plastic feels cheap, but it works fine for what it is, needless to say this is a BIG card and takes up around two and a half PCIe Slots, so consider this in mind with the length also being about 342mm.

Otherwise this is the best graphics card I have owned and I recommend it for a "budget" high end card to play 1080p games on high.

Reviews.title: Absolute beast
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2019
Reviews.text:
Paired with a Ryzen 5 3600, X570 mobo, and ddr4 3000 this card is the 1440p sweet spot for sure. Have been playing Modern Warfare at well over 144fps on high settings.

-Pros.
• Extremely high build quality, with a full metal backplate that wraps almost completly around the card.
• very very quite, don't have exact dbs but jesus this thing at 100% is way quiter than any other card ive used.
• minimal lighting and no RGB this could be a con or a pro depending but im a minimal person when it comes to lights the only thing that is illuminated is the XFX logo in white.
• price point. For the amount of graphical power you get, at $399 this thing is amazing.
• low power consumption, i run a corsiar sf600 and this card works perfect with this psu.

-Cons
• large @2.9 slots this card needs plenty of space for proper clearance.
• weight, now for most people this isnt a problem but my case doesnt have a traditional gpu bracket as it was intended for water cooled gpu's but luckly my Gigabyte X570 I mobo has a reinforced pcie slot and its been holding up very well.

If you can fit this card, its an absolute buy. Just be sure to double check your case specs.

Reviews.title: The card has what it takes. Drivers are wonky
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2020
Reviews.text:
This card can run most games at max settings 1440p in my experience. Overclocking and undervolted it to 2000 frequency and 1135mv and made a custom fan curve took the temps down for me. Ive had it for awhile now and have played through Metro Exodus, Shadow of the Tomb Raider MW2, and alot of online gaming on a 2700x 16gb ram 3600mhz and all games run beautifully. The only downside is the drivers... AMD seems to have a bad time with their drivers. From most reviews ive read i seem to have been lucky. I experience ''black screens'' maybe once or twice a week. I highly suggest doing a clean install before putting this card in. The black screens are annoying but i dont think its the card personally. just bad drivers. who know maybe youll get lucky like me and have minimal issues.

Otherwise i recommend the card. Got it fof 369 and so far am happy with purchase

Reviews.title: Best 1440P GPU for the money!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
I'm a frugal computer builder that has been building and upgrading mine and my kids computers for the last 15 years. I always buy the GPU that will give me the best bang for the buck. That has included the GTX 8800 and most recently, the GTX 970. It was time for an upgrade and I planned to stay the course with Nvidia and the 2060 until I started reading reviews on the 5700 XT, so I decided to take a chance on AMD and bought the XFX 5700 XT. I also bought a 1440P monitor to enhance my game play visuals.

I've been using the GPU for two months and I'm very satisfied with the purchase. You can't beat the bang for the buck. Outside of having a few instances where my computer has reset during a gaming session, its been all positive. I haven't changed any of the stock settings, outside of the fan curve and have not seen the card exceed 80C during benchmarks or games. Unless I'm pushing the card extremely hard, it is very quiet. I do make sure that my drivers are up to date.

Reviews.title: Defective product, poor return, poor RMA. I'd recommend avoiding
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
Reviews.text:
TL;DR The card is defective, the seller Platinum Micro Inc Wont take back (as a return was submitted 31 days after arrival of product), Amazon can't help with a return, RMA shipping per the requested method was almost $40. I'd recommend avoiding the card.

I purchased a Nitro+ RX 570 8GB from Platinum Micro Inc on 8/29/18 and received the card 9/6/18. My wife and i were about to move so i didn't test the card until 10/4/18 when i found that there was an issue with the card. I tried to trouble shoot the problem myself through the 10/6/18 when i found some postings (see toms hardware, amd support, ect...) , that this was a known issue with the Sapphire cards and likely a bios problem. 17 and 18 series drivers i tried gave me an error reading "No AMD graphics driver is installed, or the AMD driver is not functioning properly. Please install the AMD driver appropriate for your AMD hardware" on BIOS 1 and i get frames about the same as my 5 year old 7870 on bios 2. Newer drivers read bios 2 as an RX 580 in GPU-Z and same issue with frame rates. The only way that BIOS 2 functions is with drivers that are almost a year old (17 series drivers) and makes me doubt support for current gen titles coming out this year. I filed for a return on 10/7/18 and was denied as i filed 1 day outside of the window. I first called amazon and asked about their 90 day A-Z guarantee and was told that because the seller was a 3rd party seller the 90 day guarantee didn't apply. I ran through Sapphire support for a few days before they recommended an RMA with their 3rd part RMA company, Althon Micro. Althon Micro has given me an rma number and on their email requested the use of bubble wrap and packing peanuts which with shipping ran about $40. I'm worried though that their fix for the problem is a bios re-flash which would void any factory warranty i have on this card. After this fiasco I'm avoiding sapphire cards. For the $320 that this card has cost me i should have just bought a better card and that's my recommendation to you.

Reviews.title: Replaced Defective GTX780!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2022
Reviews.text: Since we are in global shortage of everything, my 2x GTX 780s in SLI decided to kaput. So I got this to hold me over. This card works perfectly fine for everything I need it to to do. I don't do much gaming anymore, but I like to have high end cards for the times when I want to game. Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Italy on July 9, 2022
Reviews.text:
Ho acquistato questa scheda grafica ASUS perché pensavo che ASUS fosse il top ma purtroppo ho dovuto ricredermi almeno su alcune caratteristiche di questo articolo. Nonostante sia stata pensata per sistemi Gaming Entry Level e per sistemi HTPC non riesce a gestire se non con affaticamento eccessivo la modalità DirectWrite (Direct2D). Infatti se uso una applicazione che ha bisogno di questa modalità il mio PC inizia a rallentare parecchio e la temperatura della GPU sale di 5 punti. Avendola acquistata per usare un Monitor 4K HDR da 28 pollici Samsung sono rimasto molto deluso nel vedere questo glitch. Per il resto è esageratamente alta il ché ha comportato che lo slot PCI-E 2.0X4 è stato occupato dalla scheda che come ingombro ha finito per nascondere lo slot, potrei anche spostare la scheda video sull'altro slot PCI-E 3.0X16 ma è troppo vicino alla CPU e alla sua ventola da 120 mm, dunque per me è un grosso problema, per il resto essendo un cooler di tipo passivo non fa rumore e anche se sale la temperatura non c'è rischio di bruciare o rompere la ventola perché non ci sono parti meccaniche. I 4K HDR li raggiunge a 60 Hz senza problemi, gli aggiornamenti dei driver li faccio direttamente dal sito ASUS invece di nVidia perché i driver che rilascia ASUS sono ottimizzati per questa scheda video. Ho una scheda madre ASUS Maximus Gene VII, un processore i7 4790K a 4.00 Ghz, 16 GB di RAM DDR3 a 1600 Mhz in dual channel, SSD da 512 GB, Monitor 4K HDR 28 pollici Samsung e due Hard Disk meccanici da 3 TB ciascuno WD RED. In 4K HDR la scheda fa 55 gradi centigradi a riposo d'estate, in inverno 47 gradi centigradi. Raggiunge i 70 gradi centigradi sotto sforzo, i giochi faticano tantissimo e li devo giocare alla risoluzione FullHD sia pure con dettagli al massimo. Nel complesso è un buon compromesso, occupa un solo slot del case e viene fornita con una staffa anche a basso profilo intercambiabile. Ovviamente ci faccio girare tranquillamente Windows 10 64bit. Vi lascio alle mie foto dalle quali vi potrete rendere meglio conto di ciò che ho scritto qui.

Valutazione complessiva:

Risoluzione 4K HDR (a 60 Hz): ★★★★★
Velocità di risposta del motore grafico: ★★
Capacità di raffreddamento: ★★★★★
Compatibilità con applicazioni moderne: ★★★
Prezzo: ★★★★★
Ingombro: ★★★★★
Uscita HDMI: ★★★★★

Conclusione: ottima ma non eccellente. Un buon prodotto entry level per aggiornare un PC che ha qualche annetto di troppo. Valutazione finale: ★★★★

Grazie!

Reviews.title: The jury is still out
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2022
Reviews.text:
I'm not a gamer, so I can't comment on that aspect. The image is nice and crisp and works well with the various graphics and animation packages I use. Watching videos on my 4K TV and they look really really good, even low res AVIs.

However, this card has some serious quirks. I have a Windows theme going, and whenever the pictures on the monitors change, they all blink rapidly over the course of two or three seconds. There have been times when the screen has just gone black for about the same length of time. At first, it was annoying but livable. Lately, however, they are happening more and more. In my experience, that means the card is getting ready to fail. We'll see.

There are absolutely no instructions anywhere for this card, not even a recommended location to download drivers. That's not a problem if you're experienced with PCs, but if you aren't, that could be a stumbling block.

I am also irritated that they didn't include any SFF brackets. This is not a cheap card (granted, it's not an expensive card either). Selling them as an add-on seems unnecessary. (I happened to have an old card with brackets that fit.)

I will probably continue to look for another card, though I'm hoping prices will become more reasonable.

EDIT: Well, the card continued to decline until it locked up the PC. Swapped out and put in my old card, which at least works. I'll leave the rating at 3 stars and assume I just got a lemon, but I'm not impressed with the quality control.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: perfect card for my sff build
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
Reviews.text:
ok this is going to be a long one so bare with me here but i think it will clear a lot of quistions up that seem to be on peoples mind when contemplating purchasing this exact model rx 5700xt by power color(axrx 5700xt 8gbd6-3dh)

ok first this is not a big card, I knew it was going to be on the small side but i did not expect it to be no bigger than the older model rx 570s from the likes of gigabyte or xfx and actually when i hold them up side by side this card is actually smaller than my Nvidia rtx 2060 super founders card and that was a surprisingly small card, so this is a perfect size for the case i have included in the photos thats the case i have put this card into
--given this cards petite build and very light weight i had ZERO expectations for good thermal management...but continue reading and i think i will effectively covey just how wrong i was about that but keep in mind that this case has the gpu literally right on the side with a massive intake basically spanning the entire side of the case were the pcie slot is so that is undoubtedly influencing my thermals and fan noise
ok on to performance. first lets identify my hardware here with a list of my parts that are in this build so we can get a better idea of how well this runs as a complete product because how useless are gpu performance and thermal numbers without knowing full system specs and how the performance and thermals of a graphics card influences total system performance
*case - silverstone sugo sg13b mesh
*cpu - intel i7 8700k
*cpu cooler - corsair h60(2018) 120mm closed loop liquid cooler
*motherboard - msi z370i pro carbon mini itx
*ram - corsair vengance pro ddr4 16gb(2x8gb) at 3600mhz at cas16
*ssd - samsung 950 pro(first gen) m.2 nVME 512gb ssd for windows 10
*ssd - silicon power a40 256gb sata 2.5in ssd for a cut down debian linux install for phoronix test suite(for testing)
*hdd - Western Digital white label 8TB red drive that runs at 5900rpm pulled from a WD external drive
*psu - Thermaltake white label 700watt 80+ white certified( this was a concern at first as i was not confedent this was going to be able to power all my hardware reliably and altho i have long term usage concerns now after i replaced the 120mm fan with a pwm fan and ran the pwm signal wire to the motherboard for advanced thermal control i am not worried at the moment but i will look into picking up a at least bronze certified of the same specs but also keep in mind that with this form factor the only system fans i have are the intake 120mm for the AIO cooler and the 120mm on the power supply so i needed to mod this in order to have more granular control of both fans and i must say im super stoked that i did because all that in this case makes for a perfect air duct from the front over the board and out the back via the psu now adding a relatively hot GPU into the mix was the last thing i wanted but looking at the total system performance im shur glad i did because of the way this case is built this gpu easily pulls in its own fresh air from the side and throws ip up towards the vents on top so even if this gpu hits 90c on the junction it end up having very little effect on full system temps
ok giving all those specs i was not expecting super high performance even tho there is no reason a i7 8700k cant still handle high fps gaming at a modest 2560x1440 at around 120 to 144fps and to my suprise it did just fine
ok on to the thermals wich is arguably the most concerning for people when considering this card and unless i completely won the silicon lottery it duz not need to concern anybody i fan a full 6 hour stress test in furmark and shur my junction temps came close to 90c but never hit that but the core stayed under 80c the hole time and the memory temps stayed under 60c the whole time, ran ran this stress test in conjunction with a small fft stress on my cpu so i could get a total system thermal worse case and that were these temps came from when i just ran the furmark stress test i didn't come anywhere near this high of temps on the card and all together i dont think i ever got higher than 30c above ambient here in Nebraska were its getting a little chili out lol
ok so here are my final thoughts on this, if you are looking for a amd gpu that is very high performance and you dont want to wait for maybe ever for rdna 2 and you need something that is going to fit into a small case with good airflow this is the card for you also it has the added bonus of being slightly obscure so the prices are usly the lowest for a new rx 5700xt at least at the time of righting this, now that being sead if you can afford the price and physical real estate of going with a bigger card with possibly 3fans you will simply have much better performance numbers and even possibly be able to overclock a little bit (by that i mean allow watt man to overclock for you as its basically fully automated at this point im super excited about that little development as i also have the giant xfx rx 5700xt thik 3 model that is setup with dual bios so i can take one and just go to town on the overclock and push close to 220watts, but thats for a different review that i will also be making here on that once my absolute army of tests is done
ok now to address so other concerns i was reading on other reviews...right now as of today the 15th of October 2020 i am running the latest optional drivers from amd and i am seeing ZERO instability and the thermals and total power consumption are well within spec( at he hottest my card was pulling 180watts) and that is with the stock performance setting on wattman no over volt or overclock or the opposite i didn't under clock anything either i specifically wanted to find out what the OUT OF BOX experience was going to be like so i could put some information out there for others to help them make a decision on this seemingly to good to be true obscure graphics card from power color and i believe i have done that...\
my conclusion is if PCPARTSPICKER list is saying this is the best card that will fit in your build than buy it if there are clear options for bigger cards like the red devil or the asus strix than buy one of those instead or even the xfx thic 3 but i have heard of thermal issues with the thic 2 but in reality if your running a normal size none sff case the 3 fan thic 3 is going to fit its no bigger than any other 3 slot card(actually uses only 2 pcie slots but the card itsslef is super thick and takes up 3 internally) ok but thats not the point here were discussing the axrx 5700xt 8gbd6-3dh
and on that in my experience everybody can set aside there performance concerns and thermal concerns as long as you have good airflow to it this card will run fine
ps after running all the stess tests i dont think my cards fans were ever hitting above 60% or if they were they were just rely quiet and at idle they are off so all in all its not a load card and keep in mind in my case the gpu intake is literally less than an inch from the side vents so i rely was expecting this to be a bit louder and just to clarify i run this system backwards with the io facing me so the gpu was also facing me and still total syste noise was negligible and actually quieter than when i had the rtx 2060 super fe in here as its idle fan speed was like 40% and ramped up to 90 within 5mins of a stress test now am i disparaging nvidia here for there FE coolers NO i love that card but i put that into an even more space constrained aluminum box from aliexpress its very nice and it is a matx sff build nut that was literally the only high performance modern gpu that would fit as it has the power cables on the side and not the top were there is literly no room in between the side aluminum panel and the top of the gpu so i had to sacrifice my more expensive 2060s on that build and that is why i was looking for a replacement for this one as its an older intel platform and not my primary rig but i jumped into this fully expecting to haf to down clock this to basically a 5700 not xt specs or even a 5600 and for the price i was totaly ok with that and was actually one of the deciding factors in picking this model as it uses the reference pcb the from stock rx 5700xt so future water cooling a gpu inside this RIDICULOUSLY small case was just kind of exciting lol and still not off the table now that i find out this card runs just fine at fully stock and is very competitive with my bigger RTX 2070super FE thats what was rely surprising as i paid 499 for that and no were near that for this and ironically this card will perform way better in linux as it is native MESA vesa and will not need to leverage nvidia to volcan runtime conversions and im no levelonetechs but i know my way around linux and rely enjoy tinkering with it and this will enable some pretty good performance numbers for paired with this easly clocked to 5ghz water cooled 8700k so ya im not regretting this purchase one bit...
but dont misunderstand me if i find any problems with this card long term i will definitely update this review and then you as a buyer can decide if those issues are a deal breaker in the future but likely there will already be a slurry of other options out there especially once RDNA2 comes to the DIY space but for now and for a while RDNA1 is what we have available as amd is still leveraging market share from the next gen consoles which are using RDNA2 so they will likely try to enjoy the win there for a while befor putting that tech on the DIYPC market and reaffirming the PC as the performance king over any console that way they get 2 wins and quite frankly after the whole FX dry spel and the rx vega flop they kinda need the wins...

...update...ok so 3 months and one debacle of a election later this card is still working perfectly and is even more stable today still using the optional rolling release drivers as opposed to the slightly older LTS drivers so ya no problembs at all...one slight complaint and it's not even a real one but a superficial one with the light weight feel of the whole card, is it is a small card and since it realy dosnt produce the kinda heat a overclocked card running at over 200watts it dosnt need anything more than a cheap light aluminum cooler stack but it still feels cheap lol ...this dosnt effect performance at all at least in this specific card as it simply dosnt need a more dence cooling solution so no real complaints just that one very first world one lol
