Reviews.title: Definitely not worth the price I paid
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2021
Reviews.text:
So right during the height of the pandemic I was trying to put together an elite desktop computer. I bought all the AMD peripherals that I could get my hands on and yes it was very expensive. I have always used AMD CPUs throughout their history and have loved and hated them. That being said I have never been a big fan of their video cards instead relying on Nvidia. I gambled with this build and purchased the RX 6900 XT and I have been disappointed ever since. This is unfortunate as again I’m a big AMD fan.

This is supposed to be AMDs flagship and I continue to have problems with chattering at high resolutions across many games and older games at that (Witcher Wild hunt), Doom, MechWarrior 5, Grim Dawn. Additionally have stability issues with older games like civilizations V and Supreme Commander 2 Forged Alliance….. The list goes on and on with my disappointment. It is very unfortunate that I have to go back to Nvidia, not that I don’t love them its just I like to have choices an I only have one choice right now.

Reviews.title: Great Video Card!!! Best card I have ever had and future proof!!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
Reviews.text:
This is the best card I have ever had, very fast, very detailed and if you have 4K monitors , it has a wonderful picture and great textures. 99% of my games run at the highest settings. It runs hot on games that are not fully compatible, but I just adjusted my settings for that one game and it is fine. I have not tried to render video yet, but I am certain that I will have the same great results. There is only one card that can compete with the Sapphire Nitro+ AMD Radeon RX 6900 XT and that is the NVIDIA RTX 3090. But the kicker is ,you need to have and want to spend $3,500.00 plus in this crazy market right now. The 3090 does out perform this card slightly, but nothing worth $3,500.00 and the benchmarks that show these findings are computer generated and would not be detected by the human eye. In addition, this is all with the default settings. You can achieve greater results by manual tuning with the Radeon software.

With the default Radeon software, under the performance tab and manual settings, I configured it to perform at 2525MHz @ 303Watts. I could have gone higher, with both Frequency and Watts, but I wanted to keep my temps down. You need to adjust the settings manually to get better results than the presets modes. You can save your settings to a file and it will keep those settings even after you reboot or shutdown. If you preform a driver update, you will only need to apply your profile settings after the update. All really easy with the default software.

Reviews.title: Extremely fast- requires some tweaking
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
Reviews.text:
Card is extremely high quality, extremely fast, and huge. You're never gonna get "bang for the buck" with a card like this but if you simply want bragging rights this will do the trick.

Some things to note:

Make absolutely sure you don't daisy chain a single power cable into each 8 pin connector- you need a separate cable from your power supply going into each 8 pin power connector.

By default this card limits its own power draw to below spec and that limits performance. This is a 300 watt card but default setting limits it to drawing 250 watts and even rage mode limits it to drawing 280 watts- both of these result in performance that is below what it should be stock(not sure if this is a Sapphire issue or an AMD driver issue). Make sure you set your profile to manual and set the power tuning limit to max- this will allow the card to draw the full 300 watts and clock itself the way AMD intended under load. I also suggest editing the fan curve because the stock fan curve is a little conservative(favoring quietness and allowing higher temps). Enjoy.

Reviews.title: The card has issues..... But performs OK when its working.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
Reviews.text:
I have had this card for 4 months or so. Every few days it goes through a phase where it will freeze. It says driver error, then crashes everything. It DOES NOT handle ray tracing like the NVIDIA counterpart. Not that it's a huge deal, NATIVE 4K still looks good. But i thought i could go all AMD and be happy, Not the case. doing it over, AMD processor, NVIDIA GPU. This is due to the 3080 having better performance at roughly half the price...

If i HAD to do an all AMD build again, i would choose the 6800XT considering the price for this is double and you only get(10% or so) a small increase in performance. I don't want to quote benchmarks because google is full of them

BUT, in this market, i was taking what i could get... It does have some advantages though... I'm not an expert or a streamer so this is just an opinion of an average gamer... Don't spend the money until they work out the driver bugs...... and only buy if you have no other options......

Worth the value? Maybe...if you seek 4K or 100FPS, sure. But for longevity at modest resolutions? Maybe not so much.

The biggest con is the RX 6000s don't yet seem to support Raytracing in anything I own... Valhalla, Cyberpunk, Control...

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
Reviews.text:
I recently built my first gaming pc in 20 years. I ordered everything but the graphics card, and when I went to research and price them... Whoa! Man have things changed in 20 years! Needless to say I needed something until I could afford a good graphics card. Enter MaxSun Radeon RX550. This card actually impressed me. Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.title: Works Great. No Extra Power Needed.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
Reviews.text: I needed a low profile video card for a small form factor computer that didn't require it's own power source, and didn't cost a fortune. This one fit all 3 requirements. It was a simple install and the software was easy to find and download.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022

No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.title: Definitely not worth the price I paid
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2021
Reviews.text:
So right during the height of the pandemic I was trying to put together an elite desktop computer. I bought all the AMD peripherals that I could get my hands on and yes it was very expensive. I have always used AMD CPUs throughout their history and have loved and hated them. That being said I have never been a big fan of their video cards instead relying on Nvidia. I gambled with this build and purchased the RX 6900 XT and I have been disappointed ever since. This is unfortunate as again I’m a big AMD fan.

This is supposed to be AMDs flagship and I continue to have problems with chattering at high resolutions across many games and older games at that (Witcher Wild hunt), Doom, MechWarrior 5, Grim Dawn. Additionally have stability issues with older games like civilizations V and Supreme Commander 2 Forged Alliance….. The list goes on and on with my disappointment. It is very unfortunate that I have to go back to Nvidia, not that I don’t love them its just I like to have choices an I only have one choice right now.

Reviews.title: Great Video Card!!! Best card I have ever had and future proof!!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
Reviews.text:
This is the best card I have ever had, very fast, very detailed and if you have 4K monitors , it has a wonderful picture and great textures. 99% of my games run at the highest settings. It runs hot on games that are not fully compatible, but I just adjusted my settings for that one game and it is fine. I have not tried to render video yet, but I am certain that I will have the same great results. There is only one card that can compete with the Sapphire Nitro+ AMD Radeon RX 6900 XT and that is the NVIDIA RTX 3090. But the kicker is ,you need to have and want to spend $3,500.00 plus in this crazy market right now. The 3090 does out perform this card slightly, but nothing worth $3,500.00 and the benchmarks that show these findings are computer generated and would not be detected by the human eye. In addition, this is all with the default settings. You can achieve greater results by manual tuning with the Radeon software.

With the default Radeon software, under the performance tab and manual settings, I configured it to perform at 2525MHz @ 303Watts. I could have gone higher, with both Frequency and Watts, but I wanted to keep my temps down. You need to adjust the settings manually to get better results than the presets modes. You can save your settings to a file and it will keep those settings even after you reboot or shutdown. If you preform a driver update, you will only need to apply your profile settings after the update. All really easy with the default software.

Reviews.title: Extremely fast- requires some tweaking
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
Reviews.text:
Card is extremely high quality, extremely fast, and huge. You're never gonna get "bang for the buck" with a card like this but if you simply want bragging rights this will do the trick.

Some things to note:

Make absolutely sure you don't daisy chain a single power cable into each 8 pin connector- you need a separate cable from your power supply going into each 8 pin power connector.

By default this card limits its own power draw to below spec and that limits performance. This is a 300 watt card but default setting limits it to drawing 250 watts and even rage mode limits it to drawing 280 watts- both of these result in performance that is below what it should be stock(not sure if this is a Sapphire issue or an AMD driver issue). Make sure you set your profile to manual and set the power tuning limit to max- this will allow the card to draw the full 300 watts and clock itself the way AMD intended under load. I also suggest editing the fan curve because the stock fan curve is a little conservative(favoring quietness and allowing higher temps). Enjoy.

Reviews.title: The card has issues..... But performs OK when its working.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
Reviews.text:
I have had this card for 4 months or so. Every few days it goes through a phase where it will freeze. It says driver error, then crashes everything. It DOES NOT handle ray tracing like the NVIDIA counterpart. Not that it's a huge deal, NATIVE 4K still looks good. But i thought i could go all AMD and be happy, Not the case. doing it over, AMD processor, NVIDIA GPU. This is due to the 3080 having better performance at roughly half the price...

If i HAD to do an all AMD build again, i would choose the 6800XT considering the price for this is double and you only get(10% or so) a small increase in performance. I don't want to quote benchmarks because google is full of them

BUT, in this market, i was taking what i could get... It does have some advantages though... I'm not an expert or a streamer so this is just an opinion of an average gamer... Don't spend the money until they work out the driver bugs...... and only buy if you have no other options......

You can run every game with more than 100fps in 4k.
Image quality is out of this world. I came from EVGA 2080Ti Ultra and it run fine just for fine for just 2 month then came the pandemic issue. Hope people understand that AMD is back. :)

Reviews.title: Beautiful and solid performer.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2021
Reviews.text:
A very tough card. I don't think it will see it's limits pushed anytime soon. Pretty much I ran Cyberpunk at 1440P, Ultra at 90-100 FPS. I bumped the resolution to 1800p and was getting between 80-90. Never really ever heard the fans. I may be CPU limited to completely push it and get it hot however, as I am on a 3700X. Still the 3700X makes this GPU sing well enough. However since I'm not a framerate wh*re I cap the frames to 60, via Radeon Chill.

Worth the value? Maybe...if you seek 4K or 100FPS, sure. But for longevity at modest resolutions? Maybe not so much.

The biggest con is the RX 6000s don't yet seem to support Raytracing in anything I own... Valhalla, Cyberpunk, Control...

Reviews.title: Scalped by a miner…

Story is, I bought it for over 2 grand when scalping was really bad, when I received the card the packaging was open and not sealed but I didn’t think anything of it, that is until I went to use it and was getting the worst performance I’ve ever seen, my old 2080 super was performing far better than this was “brand new”
The person who sold it to me, used the card for what I’m assuming was crypto mining, as the card is behaving like it’s years old and can’t handle even old titles like apex legends above 90 FPS on low settings.
Pitiful, avoid this seller at all costs.

Reviews.title: Great card in its time - Windows 10 support might be an issue
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2013
Reviews.text:
I purchased this video card to upgrade an older model video card (Radeon HD 3450) in a Dell OptiPlex 960 small form factor machine. Low profile, moderate power consumption, and very low price, were required. Also, AMD has consistently provided excellent Linux support by continuously updating their Radeon HD video driver. Without the proprietary driver, Linux defaults to a generic VGA-style driver that doesn't provide hardware optimizations.

I was kind of pushed into this upgrade, since I wanted to move to the latest CentOS release. The new release requires a newer version of the AMD driver, and that new driver no longer supports the old Radeon HD 3450. So looking around on amazon.com, it wasn't too difficult to come across this newer Radeon HD 5450 card, available at a very good price (less that $20 with a short-term post-purchase rebate that I grabbed). I've since moved to the latest Ubuntu Studio release (which already had several of the applications I was struggling to install on CentOS), and the AMD driver and new video card work great on that, too.

As noted in other reviews, the low profile bracket has a misplaced mounting hole for the HDMI connector. This issue is not a problem, since the two mounting screws on the DVI connector are completely sufficient for the mounting.

*** Updated 31-Jan-14 ***
Updating this review since I've just purchased a second card based on good experience with the first one (and another rebate program was in effect). The new one is now installed in a Dell OptiPlex 980 SFF running Windows 8.1. Windows detected the change of graphics card and Windows Update offered to install the current AMD driver. System and new graphics card work great.

*** Updated 26-Aug-16 ***
DisplayPort output failed - solid red only is displayed. DVI port still works. (Problem isolated to the card since I tried two cables and two monitors with the same results.)

In thinking this over, I became suspicious that this was yet another Windows 10 issue. And sure enough, the forums have ample reports of AMD DisplayPort problems on Windows 10. Using the DVI connector, I downloaded and installed AMD's "Radeon Software Crimson Edition Beta", which then appeared in Device Manager as v.15.301.1901.0. This update appears to resolve the problem. However, AMD notes "This driver is provided 'as is' and will not be supported with further updates, upgrades or bug fixes."

Reviews.title: Great HTPC card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2013
Reviews.text:
I purchased this for my HP HTPC system used solely for the purpose of streaming and watching movies. I didn't need to be a video-game champion or anything like that. For what I needed it for it serves its job beautifully and without issue. The system in question is fairly old and it was pretty choppy on high-resolution videos because of it. Now with this card the picture quality comes out beautiful and I don't have stuttering framerates anymore.

I would recommend it for anyone who has specific needs for it. If you're getting it to with hopes of playing all your games at 60fps 1080p or something, well, you really shouldn't be looking at this card. Its a great card if you're not going into it with high-expectations.

Update:
The card still works. However two months ago the pc started bluescreening. I though it was a graphics driver issue because the BSOD code or whatever kept pointing to ATI something or the other. Long story short, the thing was overheating and crashing. I'm not really sure why it decides to do this now, it was working fine up till this point streaming movies pretty much 24-7. Maybe the thermal paste needs to be replaced... but it feels like the heatsink is absorbing the heat well enough - it physically burns the skin to the touch, ouch!

I 'fixed' this by mounting a small fan to the side of the case that blows air directly across it. It hasn't blue screen since. However the case the pc was originally in didn't have a place for a fan on the side panel so I did have to swap cases out too. I already had a spare case (go figure) so it didn't cost me anything. Still, if you plan to use this in a small little case with poor ventilation you may want to consider a card that has a little fan on it to help keep it cool.

If you're not using it in such a small hotbox of a case however you should be just fine. If not, smack a fan in there somewhere and that should take care of it. Did for me anyway.

Reviews.title: Been working great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2014
Reviews.text:
I bought this to replace a fully functional Nvidia card that was regularly crashing Windows 8 and 8.1. The PC I use this in is set up to run either Win 7 or 8 (now 8.1). 8 crashed repeatedly, which I thought was 8's fault. I eventually realized the problem had to be related to the Nvidia card even though there were no problems with Win 7. I did some googling and found out the Nvidia's drivers are not fully compatible with Win 8 and can cause MAJOR crashes. We're not talking just BSOD's, we're talking SO much damage to the file system that the OS has to be reinstalled.

Since I replaced the Nvidia card with this, Win 8.1 has been quite stable, so the problem was definitely the Nvidia drivers.

One thing I don't like about the card is the order of the three output connectors. To take the card in and out of a slot I have to remove the top screw "post". I don't know the technical term. The top connector is VGA, middle is HDMI and bottom is DVI. As is common for VGA connectors, when you plug in the connector there are two extended screws to hold the connector in place. Those screws fit into matching threaded "posts" above and below the VGA connector. On this one the top "post" is so near the top of the slot at the back of the PC that I have to remove the post to install or remove the board. If they had put the HDMI connector on top it wouldn't be a problem. (They may have put the VGA at the top so the card could fit in a low profile slot.)

I don't do gaming or video editing, but the card is a great value and works for all the other things folks normally use a PC for. It runs well with either 32-bit Win 7 Home or Win 8.1 Pro.

Although I basically haven't used AMD's Catalyst Control Center (which *is* installed), I do like the fact that it allows detailed control of all sorts of attributes, such as GPU scaling, color temperature control, etc.

Reviews.title: It won't win any power contests, but it drives two monitors for cheap.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2015
Reviews.text: It's a pretty decent card for the price. I picked this up for my workplace computer. We recently got some new workstations that are form-factor Dell Optiplex machines that replaced our old mini-ATX tower computers. My old setup had integrated graphics that would run two monitors and I immediately missed that functionality with the new Dell. So, I went searching Amazon for the cheapest dual-output graphics card I could find. In short time I came across this XFX card. I've always had good luck with AMD/ATi in the past but this is my first experience with an XFX-branded card. I like that it came with two brackets to mount both outputs in low-pro mode. The screw hole that holds the HDMI output on the bracket didn't line up properly, but no biggie. It did not come with any mounting screws, I had to rob some from an old case (the new case didn't have any pre-installed). My only complaint is the ribbon cable holding the VGA output on is pretty short. My install situation forced me to put the VGA on top of the DVI and that stretched the ribbon to it's absolute limit. A little more slack would be nice for situations like mine. Otherwise it's a nice card - I'm not using for gaming, I just wanted two outputs on one card for as little money as possible. It won't win any power contests but I'm not expecting anything more than what it's doing: driving two monitors.

Reviews.title: Helped to ressurect my Dell E310!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2014
Reviews.text: I bought this after researching a fix for my Dell E310 video card upgrade. I needed something that would get my outdated PC running Ghost Recon, Halo and Minecraft for my kids Win 7 computer. Well this coupled with the PCI Express PCI-E 1X to 16X Slot Riser Card Flat Flexible Extension Cable (wire 19cm,total 24cm) , some minor case and wiring modifications, it worked perfectly. The XFX says that it required a power supply upgrade, but seems ok after 4 hours of gameplay. I had to splice into the +12v wires that go to the dvd burner, in addition to adding a +12v fan into the same splice to help cool the card. The software says that the card is running at 36 deg. C. The case modifications include splitting the card into two sections, with the included brackets: (A) the VGA output, the other (B) the DVI/HDMI output. (The entire thing together wouldn't fit into the PCI slots in the case, due to the clearance of the VC and riser plug into the bottom.) The section with the DVI/HDMI is too short, so I formed a straight piece of steel 1" x 1/4" that goes under the card, and pulls it forward toward the back of case. I then drilled/screwed this into place. If anyone ever tries this, you will see what I mean. The fan I mounted on the inside of the case, parallel to the card, and "L" bracketed to the back of the case near the vent holes. I know this sees like a lot of work to resurrect an old PC, but whatever, it works!

Reviews.title: Good Card! Not so good driver package.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2013
Reviews.text:
I purchased thie card after reading one of the threads at the reduser forum because people in that thread stated it supported 3840x2160 resolution @ 30Hz (which is the resolution/refresh of my 39" & 50" Seiki TVs.

Turns out, this card is not HDMI 1.4a compliant so it will only support a resolution of up to 1920x1080 via the HDMI port.

That's not the card's fault. It's mine for not catching that bit of information before I ordered it.

It came well packaged, in its box, but Amazon sent it in a padded enevlope. (?!?!)

I'm taking off 2 stars, not because of any faults of the card itself, but because of XFX's setup program. The set up program should not try to access the internet to check for the latest version. I say this for 2 reasons;

1 If I wanted the latest version of the driver software, I'd have downloaded them beforehand, thrown the Driver CD in the trash, and went about my merry way installing the drivers. When I tried to opt out of checking for the latest version, it crashed the installer program. Tried again and same thing happened.

2 The system I installed this into uses a severely throttled and metered internet access (pay as you go) so having the installer automatically check for and download the latest version is not something I wanted or intended to do on this particular computer system.

In the end, I had to borrow a friend's laptop and internet connection to grab the latest reference drivers because of the installer crashes.

Overall, this is an abberation for XFX. I've had at least 14 of their cards over the last decade and I have been more than pleased with them.

Reviews.title: The graphics card is functioning fine so far
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2014
Reviews.text:
I give this product 4 out of 5 stars because contrary to the product description does NOT come with low-profile bracket.

I repeat, it does NOT come with low-profile bracket.

So if you have an old school large form factor PC, this isn't a problem. However, it is getting increasingly aggravating ordering things from Amazon and getting products not as advertised.

If you have a small form factor PC, you will need to order an additional low-profile bracket. Or you can do as I did and fabricate one from the existing bracket. Which honestly isn't that hard to do with some basic tools. I used large pliers, dremel tool, small anvil and ball peen hammer.

This product is currently installed in an older Dell OptiPlex 755 with factory power supply which I believe is 275 watts. The graphics card is functioning fine so far. I primarily built this box for a multi media and streaming box for my home theater. I am not doing any heavy gaming with this card. Streaming HD movies my factory power supply is handling this card fine, the power supply is not getting hot so I don't think this power supply will be an issue despite the manufactures recommendations.

Reviews.title: XFX AMD Radeon HD 5450 1GB PCIe Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2015
Reviews.text:
This video card works great and a low cost upgrade for most desktops.

I bought this card because I wanted to upgrade my desktop HP DC5850 to play games like Borderlands

I was told MOST PCIe Video Cards need a 300watt power supply or better, and the DC5850 only has a 240w
After a very. very long search thru a ton of tech sites I can up a handful of Video Cards that SHOULD work with a lower end power supply
One of the interested insights I found, that a passive heatsink on a video card uses less watts

So, the 5450 was on the list of a handful of video cards and had a passive heatsink, and a half height backplates included.

I have had the video card running now for about 3 months and no problems.
I would recommend this card if you looking to upgrade your video on a desktop with a low end power supply.

One bad thing, the half height back plates don't match up the the card so the single screw over the DVI port won't line up.
I don't think you really need it. But it annoying...

Reviews.title: Good For Basic Gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2014
Reviews.text:
I would give it 5 stars because it is a perfect cheap graphic card. But my computer needs low profile brackets, and luckily it came with them. That was great but the only problem was I got 2 brackets that were the same! I couldn't fit my VGA slot in the bracket, that was extremely frustrating!!

Anyway onto the card, the card is a very good card. It has 1 GB of video ram gives you very good frame rates on low end games. Most of the games I played I was able to play at medium settings with a decent frame rate. There would be a few drops here and there but otherwise it was very steady.

It also recommends you need a 400 watt power supply but I think you would be okay with a 350 watt or higher.

If you need a cheap, good, reliable GPU (Graphics Card) then this is the card for you. But I wouldn't recommend buying it at regular price, I got my for $29.99 but it is not worth it for $50.

Reviews.title: Its eh for gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2020
Reviews.text:
have had it for like half a year and the fan is kinda broken it decides to just spin slowly and then i have to kick start it and spin it with my finger to spin correctly card still works just kinda a bummer

Edit: Before when i wrote this review i was a pleb but i have done my research and realized what a mistake i made buying this card. I replaced this for a 1050ti and holy crap did it feel alot more snappy. With the 1050ti i could run 144hz but with this one i can only run 60hz. I sold the 1050ti and switched back to this one in the meantime so i could still do my stuff on my pc but when i tried to play my games it ran horribly. Also, it makes my monitors colors look idk more gray, i have a Asus vg279q so it has good colors and 144hz but this gpu just takes that all away. I ran fortnite on performance mode and at 50% 3d resolution and it ran at barely 60fps. Then i tried Forza Horizon 4 and i got 15 fps MAX so yeah pretty bad. I overclocked it so now it runs 25 fps in FH4 so better but not great, and i can only put the 3d resolution up to 60% now with the overclock. After the overclock the screen started artifacting (black spots and lines on the screen) while gaming but it didnt bother me so i kept it like that. So to conclude, its not the best card for gaming and you'd be better off with integrated graphics, that being said if your pc doesnt have a IGPU i would get this card assuming its only for work and you just need to have a image on screen. But other than that i would not recommend, your better off just getting a 1050ti (at the right price 125-150 usd) not this card.

Reviews.title: email account required to update drivers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2021

I have been an AMD person. My current video card died and I needed a quick cheap card to get me through until I was ready to buy a new pc. Installing the card was simple once I downloaded the proper installer from the Nvidia website. The CD that was included is not compatible with Windows 10.

After tweaking this card I was able to play most of my games including WOW.

I received notification from the Nvidia software that there is an updated driver. I clicked install and it forced me to create an account and sign in. I can see where this is going, ADs, targetted ADs, etc. There is no other reason to force a sign on unless they are going to data mine their customer. This is a deal breaker for me. I am going to stay with AMD.

Reviews.title: A Great Buy At The $699 MSRP, Horrible deal at scalper $800-1000 price tag
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2016
Reviews.text:
BIG CAVEAT HERE: MSRP for founders edition is $699!!! Due to inital launch limited availability "scalpers" like to soak up stock and re-sell for hundreds of dollars more, so *DO NOT BE FOOLED* HOWEVER: You may ALSO be looking for a more "human" review of this product, so let's talk about the card itself for a minute.

So. . . is the card worth it [for the $699 MSRP?] Honestly, since you're already stuck waiting, I'd go for something with a custom cooler. At completely stock settings the 1080, like all newer GTX cards, is designed to be silent THEN powerful. As a result, by design it ramps up to 83c and starts to dynamically throttle. It's nothing a custom fan profile can't fix, but the custom cooler cards [like Asus Strix 1080] are going to run cooler, clock higher [and use significantly more wattage.. I wanna say the strix listed 300w vs 180 stock] But let's be real: you're looking at a $600 card, power consumption is probably NOT the biggest priority on your list here.

So how does she GAME? Well, I can't speak to the latest AAA titles because I'm not a fan. HOWEVER: I *CAN* say that my average FPS on a dell 34" 3440 x 1440 2k monitor [which they now call 4k for some reason] with a GTX 780 was approximately 160-180 with everything maxed on Diablo 3. with the GTX 1080 on my new 27" 3840x2160 LG UD68-p 4k screen [which they now call UHD for some reason] I'm clocking 180-200 FPS with everything maxed. Given the increase in pixel density I'd call that a decent increase in frames.

I could continue to talk frames, but let's face it: there are TONS of professional reviews out there that probably have your game du jour benchmarked at 1080, 2k, and 4k against any setup of cards. You're going to look at this review and go "why even bother"? "You don't need that horesepower, what was the point"?

And to you I'd say: Occulus and Vive aren't going to be sold out forever. The 780ti would PROBABLY have worked, but I wanted guarantees, not wing-and-prayer hopes. 8 gig DDR5x takes Video ram completely out of the equasion for 4k resolutions [probably overkill still for a long time, but who knows, I can always grab another 34" LG and run surround with 4k in the middle]

Ultimately I bought this card because I wanted it and I was at the right place at the right time to score one on launch day. To reiterate I WOULD NOT PAY MORE THAN $699 LIST FOR ANY FOUNDER'S EDITION OF THIS CARD! In a few weeks the scalpers should die out, and prices should return to normal, so just wait.

"But, you haven't told us if it's WORTH it". Semi subjective, if you've already got a GTX 980ti or two I probably wouldn't bother just yet [wait for the 1080ti] but my system is quieter under load/gaming, significantly more FPS pushing more pixels. . . I'm happy with my purchase. Eventually I'll probably put an evga GPU cooler on it and start cranking things up [another thing to keep in mind, I've READ that the founders edition can be voltage limited, but if you're into heavy GPU overclocking you're probably already aware]

Ultimately your best option is to wait for the aftermarket cooled solutions, but if you're in need of a card like this and just "happen" to find one at the shelf of your local retail or e-tail store for the $699 MSRP. . .don't hesitate: She's still [probably] faster than you need

Reviews.title: The real review here
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2020
Reviews.text:
Pros

- Very affordable and accurately priced @ > $300
- Very cool gpu. Stress tests with Kombuster/Userbenchmark couldn't push the gpu above 80c before OC crash.
- Adrenalin software is interesting/Very customizable with current updates (is finally stable)
- Freesync (significantly easier to find a nice monitor for this gpu as most monitors now have freesync)
- Lots of room for over clocking and pretty damn stable compared to Nvidia
- FPS is *pretty good for the price

Cons

- Very sharp/ grainy graphical style. (NVIDIA is known for being smooth and silky while this card is grainy and sharp in most games. This is not a bad thing if you're looking for the best FPS, but i try to build systems that look amazing and function amazing. This card is more of the side of "function amazing")
- Gets crushed by the 2060 super and fairly out done by the 2060. This is a half step down from the 2060 in my book.
- Time consuming for new PC builders to get settings dialed in. I've spent probably 4-5 hours getting this card dialed in - running DDU, driver updates, general card settings in adrenaline, monitor configuration etc. Much more tweaking needed compared to an NVIDIA card buy after everything is all said and done, i like the customization this card offers.
- Not particularly amazing but a good card. Can't run warzone on max settings without a lot of performance chopping, WoW at max settings performs around 65-75 fps. Was a little disappointed at first. HOWEVER on more customized graphics/settings in adrenalin you can push the image quality down and get significantly higher performance.

OVERALL (TLDR) - I'd give this card a 7/10 for value alone. Don't expect this card to handle everything you throw at it, but do expect this card to put up pretty good performance in most scenarios.

Reviews.title: Decent card for 1080p Gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2020
Reviews.text:
This card is pretty good for 1080p gaming and even overclocking.

Overclocking was much better before vbios update that "made the card faster" but gimped it from overclocking like before due to it being able to reach 5700 speeds. So the vbios limits how much you can overclock now artificially.

Design of the card is great and the fans keep it cool, most of the time the fans don't come on as not needed. I've only heard them at 100% once and that was since I set them to 100%, during gaming they come on at about 25%-50% speed and able to cool the card off.

No RGB on the card, I don't care for RGB but if you do then this one doesn't have it. If I had to do it over again I'd prob would have gotten the 5700 or waited for the new cards but I don't do 4k gaming so just went with what I needed.

Reviews.title: MSI - Making a name for themselves! Best 5600 on the market at this time.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
Reviews.text:
Years ago I was a die-hard fan of no video card unless is was a Radeon....period. Then I made the switch to NVIDIA with my first card being the 980 Ti Classified (which I still have)...and then working through every new GPU to the current (but soon to be out-dated) RTX 2080 class.

Anyway, I wanted to get a nice mid-range card for a new build and having purchased and used an MSI Z490 chipset to support an Intel Gen 10 Core i7, the 5600 XT Gaming seemed to fit just right.

Though out of my "comfort zone" for my new builds, I have been more than pleasantly surprised at the capabilities of this card. No issues with drivers, EZ install, games are no problem, 4K looks great with additional settings in the Radeon Software to enable 10-bit panel support, and so on...

If you are looking for a great mid-range card...GET THIS CARD. You will not be disappointed.

Reviews.title: Flashed new VBIOS + Updated Drivers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
Reviews.text:
Rocky start:

When I first purchased this in early March 2020, it was extremely unstable because of the well known AMD driver issues which caused constant black screens among thousands of people. I was SO SO close to returning this thing because I had to endure these issues for a month asking myself "Did I really just spend $300 on this piece of junk??" Thankfully I hung in there for just a tad bit longer. Mid March I flashed the new VBIOS using MSI Live Updates and the black screens weren't as constant, but the issues still remained. Finally AMD released a new driver update mid March version 20.3.1 which seemed to fix the black screens and also addressed the known issues in the "What's new" portion of the driver update info.

Conclusion:

This is a 1080p killing machine! Great value for the money and can stand toe-to-toe against RTX 2060 Super but for about $100 less. Make sure to flash new VBIOS using MSI LIVE Updates and update to latest AMD drivers for RX 5600 XT.

Reviews.title: Unusual requirements, but works well
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
Reviews.text:
This card runs well once it's set up. Two caveats to consider, though:

1. It's deceptively large, measuring 297mm long, bigger than a lot of cards with 3 fans, even though it only has 2 fans. Make sure it fits in your case before you buy it.
2. Most RX 5600 XT's only need one 8-pin power connector, but this one needs two for some reason. Also, it needs the 7th and 8th pins to be connected, so plugging a 6-pin connector directly into it won't work even though it fits. If your power supply only has one 8-pin and one 6-pin connector, you'll need to use a 6-pin to 8-pin adapter to get it to work.

Reviews.title: Glad I got it when I did
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2021
Reviews.text: This card has been a little champ for us, and I'm sure glad I got it before everything went crazy with gpu's. It handled everything I asked it to do with ease. Shadow of the Tomb Raider was solid at 60+ fps on high/ultra settings. All the games we play do fine with it. Sure a 5700 XT would be better and of course mythical 6000-series radeon cards would be even better. But if you can get your hands on a 5600 XT for a reasonable price it's really not a bad investment. For what we paid (I think around $300) it's pretty hard to beat. Especially in today's market.

Reviews.title: This is the best bang for buck card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2020
Reviews.text: I bought the 2060 KO from evga and quickly saw this card after. The evga 2060 was 350 while this one is 290. I saw some YouTube videos that said this is the best card for 1080 p gaming and this is just that. I am able to get 144 FPS on med high setting in warzone! That’s nuts. I can get 144 FPS on all games I play. A good update bios from msi just go to their website and download the drivers and this card outperforms higher price cards and it has a backplate! It feels sturdy when installing and cooling idles at 37c under load I reach 60c max under heavy load and that’s with one case intake fan. I have ordered more and will notice better cooling efficiency highly recommend!

data.label: MSI Gaming GeForce RTX 2070 8GB GDRR6 256-Bit HDMI/DP DirectX 12 VR Ready Ray Tracing Turing Architecture HDCP Graphics Card (RTX 2070 Ventus GP)
data.description: NVIDIA Turing Architecture. This revolutionary architecture, combined with our all-new GeForce RTX platform, fuses together real-time ray tracing, artificial intelligence, and programmable shading. You've never created and enjoyed games like this before. Ray tracing is the definitive solution for lifelike lighting, reflections, and shadows, offering a level of realism far beyond what's possible using traditional rendering techniques. NVIDIA Turing is the first GPU capable of real-time ray tracing. GeForce RTX gaming GPUs come loaded with next-generation GDDR6 memory, support for DirectX 12 features, and more. This is graphics reinvented.

Reviews.title: Good value for an uncertain violatile GPU market.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
Reviews.text:
I noticed there are no English review's for this GPU so I will give my 2 cents about this product.

Just a disclaimer, I am not a huge nerd when it comes to specifications of hardware on computers, but i did research how to best utilize my current build and what pieces of hardware combined, gets the most out of my new PC build.

FIRST off, I decided to build a new pc,my current rig is ten years old. I research all parts including the GPU and decided the 2070 was my best bet. Though most 2070 ran in the 500 dollars and above so I was going to go for a 2060 super as an alternative but what surprised to see the MSI RTX 2070 ventis at 410 dollars.

I jumped at the opportunity and bought the card. Shortly after it was sold out and went up by 100 dollars.

IT took me 5 days to receive the card and boy I don't regret the purchase. The ventis is smaller than my old 980ti and far out performs my old card. First time buying an MSI aftermarket card but I can confidently say it's quiter then any ZOTAC aftermarket cards that I have bought.

With paired with my current rig, I run anything and everything easily over 60 FPS at 1080p. I am currently waiting to buy a 4k monitor and will update once I do.

Don't feel hesitant to buy this card, I did just because it's had very little review's versus other GPUs on amazon. At 410 dollars and how the current over blown prices of GPUs this isn't a bad deal.

Current gaming rig:
B450 Tomahawk max
3rd gen Ryzen 5 3600
Corsair vengeance 16 GB 3000 mghz ram
MSI rtx 2070 aventis
1GB Samsung evo 840
1GB Samsung evo 860
Thermatake RGB 750 watt PSU gold standard windows 10

Reviews.title: Too Bad, Scalpers!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2022
Reviews.text:
Recently purchased an ASUS TUF Gaming Radeon 6700XT from the Amazon Warehouse ... product was discounted approximately $300.00 off inflated scalper prices, and was listed as "damaged."

Fact is, only the package itself had dog-eared corners, but the package's inside contents were undamaged with no missing items. Must have just fallen off a truck or forklift for it to be listed in "good" condition.

After a month of use, the videocard is purring along effortlessly with virtually NO hiccups. But, my biggest joy is ... once again ... preventing scalpers from getting my hard-earned cash!

So ... scalpers .... if you're reading this ... how have your profit margins been, lately? Your prices seem to have gone down a bit due to your fellow scum-bag competitors entering the market. Won't be long now ... can you say "bankrupt? Bwahahahah!

data.description: AMD Radeon RX 6750 XT Phantom Gaming D 12GB OC

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Italy on September 9, 2022
Reviews.text:
Dopo due anni di attesa sono riuscito a prenderne una.
Con l'incognita delle nuove gpu in arrivo (in fatto di prezzi e reperibilità) , l'ho presa sui 500 euro e l'ho preferita alle 3060ti/3070/ti per quei 4gb di vram in più che possono renderla più ''longeva'' in futuro dato che i giochi saranno sempre più pesanti oltre che per le prestazioni più o meno simili, la differenza di prezzo e il disinteresse per features come ray tracing e dlss.
Ero dubbioso sul brand Asrock per una questione di dissipazione della scheda ma fortunatamente le temperature sono buonissime.
La scheda è silenziosa, le ventole neanche girano in idle con una temperatura sui 35 gradi, anche in game praticamente impercettibile.
Provata su God Of War, Spiderman e Cyberpunk (1080p) si è comportata bene andando di tanto in tanto sui 60-61 gradi a seconda dello scenario di gioco e del carico di lavoro della scheda, per il resto le temperature si attestano sempre sui 51-58 gradi di norma, ma basta comunque applicare un leggero undervolt e bloccare i framerate sui 60 per avere un esperienza ottima e fluida in tutti i giochi che non siano FPS.
Alimentata con un TX650M non ha mai dato problemi in questo primo mese di utilizzo.
Nella confenzione è presente solo la scheda, quindi se vi servono cavi di alimentazione (16pin) o cavi hdmi/dp sono da prendere a parte.
Avendo avuto sempre schede nvidia ed essendo questa la mia prima scheda amd per ora sono piacevolmente sorpreso e sollevato dal fatto che molte delle cose negative che si leggono, come problemi di driver, crash o altro non si sono verificati almeno nel mio caso.
La mia 750ti si è arresa solo per un limite di vram, altrimenti sarebbe ancora lì a combattere in 900/720p anche sui titoli più recenti dopo 7 anni.. speriamo che questa abbia la stessa durata..
Anche se i prezzi sono ancora alti e calano, ahimè, molto molto lentamente, ne consiglio comunque l'acquisto (quando capita in offerta sotto i 500).

I have had a long time issue with my previous graphics card when running two screens that one would black out randomly. But usually at least once per session, sometimes infuriatingly often. I had a gutsfull and looked for a replacement.
Seems a very common thing on many cards. This one seemed to have less reports so I took a punt.
When I got it I noticed the HP part in the title and if I recall correctly there was a scary note in the package saying it was only for HP machines. After some swearing and fist shaking I eventually downloaded a working driver and job's a good 'un. Been working fine and I no longer have the desire to smash the second screen up.

Reviews.title: Except for the power connector, it was a breeze...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2021
Reviews.text:
I replaced the original fan in an EVGA NVIDIA GeForce GT 730.

This worked perfectly (correct size, correct mounting arrangement), but I had trouble mating the new fan's 4-pin connector to the 2-pin connector on the old card. I accommodated this with some trouble by purchasing CRJ Mini 2-Pin Female PC Fan Adapter Cable (here on Amazon). Its 2-pin connector was a perfect fit. Its other end was a 4-pin wide connector, but with only two pins. The pin-out is crucial: you must make use of the new fan's black and yellow wires when you plug it into this extension. (I tore out part of the 4-pin connector to make this easier as you can see in the picture.)

So, if you're a bit handy, this is a great replacement fan. Almost certainly you'll need thermal paste during the replacement.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: Great for what it is
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
Reviews.text:
I recently built my first gaming pc in 20 years. I ordered everything but the graphics card, and when I went to research and price them... Whoa! Man have things changed in 20 years! Needless to say I needed something until I could afford a good graphics card. Enter MaxSun Radeon RX550. This card actually impressed me. Not only was I able to get my system up and running, I was also able to play a few of my favorite games, like BeamNG.drive. Granted, the settings were on Low and some on Medium, and the FPS wasn't optimal, but it was definitely playable.

While I wouldn't recommend this as a primary card for gaming, it makes a great backup.

Reviews.title: Great budget card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2022
Reviews.text: WOW - what a difference from my old graphics card. My PC only has a 400 watt power supply and this one plugs directly into the motherboard and doesn't require any other power cables to be connected. And I was able to take full advantage of the Radeon technology in my monitor - was able to set it to 185mhz refresh rate too. Fortnite looks 1000 times better!

data.label: MAXSUN AMD Radeon RX 550 4GB Low Profile Small Form Factor Video Graphics Card for Gaming Computer PC GPU GDDR5 ITX SFF HDPC 128-Bit DirectX 12 PCI Express X16 3.0, HDMI, DisplayPort

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.title: Works Great. No Extra Power Needed.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
Reviews.text: I needed a low profile video card for a small form factor computer that didn't require it's own power source, and didn't cost a fortune. This one fit all 3 requirements. It was a simple install and the software was easy to find and download.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.text: Precio un pelin subido pero viendo lo que hay pues no esta mal se defiende bien con juegos como the witcher 3 asi que a mi me vale.

Schnelle Karte, läuft unter Windows 11 hervorragend.
Preis Leistung ist gut.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
Reviews.text: Some of the previous reviewers had opined that there cards might have been returns. I received an open box (no factory tape on the folds) and no documentation on the inside. No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on January 11, 2021
Reviews.text:
Build Quality:
- The pipe has a glossy finish with a logo at the top most portion.
- The base and bracket piece is a matte finish.
- There is a small rubber piece glued onto the tip of the screw to prevent damage of the pipe.
- There is a magnet at the bottom of the base to allow the whole piece to stay in place without needing to screw it in or clamp it.

Functionality
- Adjust the bracket to be placed right underneath the edge of your graphics card.
- The rubber piece on the end of the screw holds the bracket in place when tightened.

The Good
- Well-built for the price.
- Easy to assemble and install.
- Nice touch on the rubber piece on the tip of the screw to prevent damage/scratching of the pipe.
- The magnet at the bottom is nice to prevent the item from moving around.

The Bad
- The rubber piece fell off during disassembling, however, it was quite easy to place it back.
- If you have a case with multiple fan holes at the bottom, the base may not stick properly as there isn't enough contact between the magnet base and your case.
- It's a tad too short to hold my GPU. Even though I have a triple-slot 5700xt, the bracket is about 1/2 inch too short. Honestly, this is my mistake. Ensure to take dimensions, from the bottom of your case to the bottom-portion of your GPU, to see if this bracket is compatible.

Reviews.title: Good value to replace onboard graphics , but no low profile bracket included!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought the v5 version for $72, which was a great price, but it didn't include the low profile bracket that was supposed to be included as per the product description. In fact, the sealed PNY box included the video card and not so much as a single sheet of paper with quick install instructions or a driver disk or anything. It literally was a video card in a protective plastic clamshell within the box and there was absolutely nothing else in the box. It isn't worth me sending it back for them to simply send me another with no bracket so I have ordered a low profile bracket from a 3rd party for around $7 that will hopefully fit. This increases the price to $79 which is still around $5 less than the next least expensive gt 1030 that I could find. I definitely find the situation irritating that the description is incorrect.

As for the card itself, I removed the large bracket and went ahead and installed it in my preowned Dell Optiplex 790. It does fit in the small form factor with no issues and will be fully secured once I receive the proper low profile bracket.

The PC I installed this video card on has an old i5-2400 processor and 8gb of ddr3 1333 ram installed. I installed Windows 10 and Tomb Raider (2013) from my Steam library. Prior to installing the video card,
on low settings at 1080p, the Tomb Raider benchmark reported an average FPS of 6. That isn't a typo. The onboard graphics were terrible. After installing the PNY GT 1030 V5, on normal settings at 1080p the benchmark is a rock-solid 60fps. This isn't a powerful gaming card, but it is a fairly economic replacement for onboard graphics on older machines. My primary gaming pc has a gtx 1050ti which is a much better low end gaming option, but for an ultra low budget build it is a competent card for light gaming needs. I tested it for a couple of hours playing the Witcher 3 and it was able to handle the game without any hitching or stutters.

With this card you should be able to play most modern games and have a reasonably good experience, but you won't typically be able to use max settings and you may need to adjust some settings per game in the Nvidia control panel. Make sure you download the Geforce Experience application onto your PC and use it to download and install your driver, since the box doesn't include any software.

For $72 this little card is more capable than I was expecting and it definitely provides a good value for the price. I would rate this at 4 stars if it had included the low profile bracket as per the item description.

Reviews.title: Boy I hate this video card drought.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2021
Reviews.text:
I paid waaaaayy too much for this thing. 6 months ago I paid $50 less for a fanless GT1030 (and only $50 more for a GTX1650 Super OC).

THIS IS NOT A $129 CARD! But it's also about the cheapest one I could find. And like my GTX1650, it came in the ultimate of generic packaging. It also doesn't have a low profile bracket - which I knew about before I bought it. What I didn't like was the fact that the screw wasn't in the bracket, and one of the retention fittings was loose -- as if someone had taken the card, tried a bracket they already had, and when that didn't work, sent it back and it got resold to me.

It works, as well as a GT1030 can work (and it does have GDDR5 memory in it), just wait for a better price drop.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2020
Reviews.text:
I had to modify the original grid bracket (by twist-to-break each bar) just so there was SOME semblance of support. It certainly doesn't hold like a solid piece that's screwed to the card would do, but it's better than nothing. I might also put a wood post between the heat sink and the power supply below it, just for some gravity-support. It's not a heavy card, but since there's no true stabilizing bracket, I don't want to stress the card's contact points.

That all being said, runs as expected. Keeps decent temps, both ports work, card itself is indeed formed for a slim case. Not a bad card at all, just not 100% compatible with slim cases as advertised....

Vr audio, physics, and haptics let you hear and feel every moment. Pascal is built to meet the demands of Next generation displays, including VR, ultra-high-resolution, and multiple monitors. It features NVIDIA game works technologies for extremely smooth game play and cinematic experiences. Plus, it includes revolutionary new 360-degree image capture. Pascal-powered graphics cards give you superior performance and power efficiency, built using ultra-fast fine and supporting direct 12 features to deliver the fastest, smoothest, most power-efficient gaming experiences.

Reviews.title: Amazingly Fast !!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2019
Reviews.text: I recently upgraded to an AMD Ryzen 5 2600 on an Asus ROG Strix B450-F Gaming MB. I then decided to buy this as an upgrade for my GTX 1060 3 GB card. All I can say is that the difference is Amazing !!!! I went from playing current games set on medium at 60 fps to playing them set on Ultra at well over 100 fps. This card also stays Very cool, maxing out at around 56 C after 3-4 hours of gaming. And I was extremely happy to find out that it automatically OC's it self up to 1965 MHZ. I ran the 3Dmark Time Spy Benchmark and was again happily surprised that this card performed better than most GTX 1070 cards and even beat out some GTX 1080 cards. This GPU also seems to be very well made and looks good (IMO) as well. Overall I am Extremely pleased with this video cards performance and cooling and would Highly recommend it to anyone looking for a Very fast GPU at a reasonable price.

Reviews.title: How far we've come
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2019
Reviews.text:
1660ti is amazing for the price. Fantastic 1080p performer, decent 1440p performer, don't expect 60fps 4k. I paid twice this for a 1070 on another build for the same /worse performance not to long ago. Some will say to go for the 2060 but personally I think this is the sweet spot for more budget oriented builds. Decent pairing with the 2600x though if you've got the extra cash an i5 will bottleneck less.

Got this varient as there was a warehouse deal on it and its black and white which matches my build. Pretty handy oc out of the box but I got mine to about 2080 or so without issue.

Reviews.title: Amazing performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2019
Reviews.text: Ok, so I've only had it 24 hours. Played Metro Exodus last night, on Ultra on a 1080 monitor. Vsync enabled, I flatlined at 60 fps. So I said wth, changed it to Extreme settings. Still flatlined at 60 fps. Ran at about 61C max and very quiet. This was a *huge* step up from the GTX 1060 I was running. I wish it was cheaper, but it still cost about $100 less than the 1060 did when I bought it this time last year. Highly recommend this card if you're looking to upgrade from a 1060.

Reviews.title: Great looking GTX 1070
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2016
Reviews.text: This is a great GTX 1070. It looks great, stays cool and performs wonderfully. I really like the white aesthetic that matches my Asus Z170-A motherboard perfectly. There are only 2 negatives I have about this card. First is there is no fan stop mode that you might find on other modern graphics cards. What this means is the fans run all the time, even at idle. It's not a huge deal as the fans are fairly quiet but I would have liked to have the feature. The second is that there is a LED on the PCB right next to the PCI power connector that stays on all the time, even when the system is powered off. I keep my PC in my bedroom so when the lights are out this little light glows quite brightly through my side panel window. Other than those small things, this is a great graphics card for the money.

Reviews.title: Worth the money
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
Reviews.text:
Found this card local on a promo for $409 in stock. I was leaning towards buying a second gtx970 to run SLI but after looking at all the specs and comparisons it seemed than counterproductive to spend about $200 on another 970 and $30 on an SLI bridge. Installed the Dual card in place of the TriFan windforce 970. So much nicer not having that giant card that barely fit in the case. The 1070 dual fit without any space issues or constraints. Install was pretty quick and straightforward. I am still old school and really only play Warcraft. I've updated everything in the last month in preparation for the new Legion release. Added a G-Sync Phillips 27" monitor on 144hz as well. My old rig was 7 years dated, though it still ran everything (previously on a GTX570) This card Runs everything on MAX and pulls 97FPS constant.

The only issue I have run into is that GeForce Experience will not load after the install of the 1070. I removed the 570 from my old rig and installed the 970 and everything still worked fine. Not sure why but I have still not been able to get GeForce Experience to work. Says cannot connect to Nvidia. My drivers are up to date. Otherwise this card is amazing. In the future I will get another and run it SLI.
