Reviews.title: Compact Size with lots of power for small cases
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2018
Reviews.text: This AORUS RX580 is quite compact and heavy. I was surprised when it ended up being the same size (while twice the weight) as my old Radeon HD 7800, which was a mid level card several years ago. This AORUS comes overclocked pretty well so I didnt need to do anything but load drivers and it kicks butt, and its even cooler and quieter than my old card. The old card only used a 6-pin, and I was delighted the RX580 uses only one 8-pin power connector. I have a small micro-ATX case. It can fit a little bigger and wider card, but I don't like taking up all the space and blocking airflow. Other RX580 cards are much larger. I recommend this card for small case gamers. For regular cases I am sure any of the RX580 lineup will do, but I have had good luck with two mid-level Gigabyte cards lasting and never failing, while a few other brands have failed over the years on me. The only reason I rate it a 4, and not a 5, is that it is a far cry from the next level of AMD Vega 56, in terms of both technology and performance. This is 2+ year old tech being used as the highest mid-level performance, rather than new tech flowing down to the mid-level for better efficiency. To get the high performance card you pay almost twice as much though, and the cards get even bigger, and require more power connectors and supplies, so there is a tradeoff. I just wish AMD had flowed its new tech down.

Reviews.title: Great buy, a bit buggy on the software end - excellent for the pricing!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2018
Reviews.text:
This card performs as I'd hoped, almost all my games running smooth on High-Ultra (with some tweaks) at 2k res, and Ultra everything at 1080p.

My problem is that I may have derped with the OC settings, and now I get an annoying LED flashing for "abnormal power supply" entering the GPU, which is lame because it performs fine and no issues have been detected, just the LED going on and off intermittently in b/w a 5-20 minute window (and sometimes blinking up to 4 times).

Hopefully, this card lasts, but if you do go for this, I highly recommend getting the 3 year protection plan as well, should something happen to it.

The Software Aorus Engine is VERY buggy, and the installation of the drivers was actually more of a hassle than I am having with the card's LED bug. But, overall I am happy with the purchase and got it on a good sale price. A valuable upgrade for sure.

EDIT: turns out that LED was a faulty PSU (which shocked me). Now the GPU is clean! The only issue remains is the buggy incompatibility of the AORUS Engine with PC as a whole. It's good to run it, and change the LEDs once and then immediately uninstall the software from your PC completely, because the GPU will have the LED color stored in memory on the card. I recommend OCing it using Afterburner from MSI if you're into OCing cards.

Reviews.title: Good Performance, Great Price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2018
Reviews.text:
This card was my idea of a GTX 1060 competitor; however, it didn't live up too much to that idea. My 1060 is a higher end 1060, so it isn't comparable, but with this graphics card, I was able to run CS:GO on 1920x1080 at an average 210fps with medium settings. This was without the most up-to-date drivers installed. With new drivers, I gained around 10fps more, which still isn't comparable to my 1060, but it is way cheaper than the 1060. The dual fans supposedly keep the card cool, but it gets really hot at times, especially if gaming at 1920x1080 for 6 hours. The RGB is only on the logo, however I did have a problem with the logo, which had some printing errors of some sort around the name, leaving holes where the RGB light passed through and shines through. I thought it looked cool, so I'm deciding to keep that. Im unsure if it was meant to be like that or not. It for some reason still gives discs, which I managed to use after using a disk reader from a 2007 Dell Inspiron 580 when I had(and still have) no internet.
Pros:
Great price per performance
Runs games fantastically at 1920x1080
Fans aren't loud
RGB!
Cool accents here and there
Backplate

Cons:
Not power efficient
Maybe a factory defect on the RGB Auros logo

Reviews.title: It's pretty good. Worth it? Probably
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2019
Reviews.text:
For the price, it's pretty decent. I have little problems with it. Though if you don't care for the RGB, I would recommend not using the AORUS software. It's bloated and just another thing running in the background. If you want to overclock the card use MSI Afterburner.

One of the only problems I came across with this card was that the temperatures were getting way too hot. After an hour of gaming the temperatures were reaching ~65°C at 1380 MHz. I ended up getting an Arctic Accelero Xtreme IV, which when fans are at nearly 100% it's quiet and keeps temperatures ~20°C idle, & ~45°C under load.

The other problem I encountered was getting Hynix memory which isn't as good as Samsung or Micron. But that also has to do with the silicon lottery, so your mileage may very.

If you have a FreeSync/ adaptive sync monitor this card is real good for that too.

It's a AMD card, so there are some pretty handy tweaks you can do to get the best bang for your buck. Like, RadeonMod and other registry changes if you're on Windows. But once again, your mileage may very.

Reviews.title: Aggravation with software issues
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2018
Reviews.text: From my standpoint, the card itself is great. Thing is, it's the most expensive and highest end card I've ever had so you have to take that with a grain of salt. The A0RUS graphic engine software plain out blows though. Well actually, I'm not sure about the software itself because I've never actually seen it. If you try to install it from the included CD, the download stops with a corrupted file message. I found and downloaded it elsewhere but it won't run. It ask if it can make changes and you see a round loading indicator and then nothing, nada, zip. It just stops as if you never clicked the icon in the first place. PC doesn't lock up, you can go on about your business but you never see the graphics engine. I only gave it an overall rating of three stars because the software issues are extremely annoying. I can't stop the light cycling or anything else. One other thing is that if the computer goes in to sleep mode for any length of time, my monitor will not come back up. This may be a setting but how would I know? I have read that others have had success working on the lights with older versions of the software but I haven't been able to find a download for anything except the current not working version. Gigabyte should really get on the stick about fixing their software. My research indicates that this program has had some long standing issues. They are ruining the rep of what, to me is a great card, because of stupid issues with the software. Yes, I tried a clean boot of Windows 10. Still no dice.

Reviews.title: Okay card, but some shortcomings.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2021
Reviews.text:
This card does mostly what it advertises, but it does have issues with some animations or some motions. Notably when I play Sea of Thieves my old GTX 1070 would smoothly render projectile animations without problems as well as sunlight, but the 580, in spite of having 8gb or VRAM, has issues with leaving trails or rendering scattered light.

It's not a bad card by any means, but has some limitations. I purchased it while it was on sale back in 2018 as a backup card for my other 960 and 1070 cards. For the price I paid it does its job and is worth the price. I would not however pay upwards of today's asking price of $800 to $1000 for what it does. You're better off buying a less expensive card.

Reviews.title: My Experience
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2018
Reviews.text: Received the GPU and ran into software issues with Gigabyte software. My advice, don’t install anything that associates with their software. The RGB is nice, can’t control much due to the software issues. Performance wise is great! The GPU only pulls around 150-180 watts which makes since, 75 from the PCIE and up to 125 from the 8 pin. I use MSI Afterburner for OCing and fan control. Anything above 60% fan speed creates some noise, so I have mine set to that. I am running it at 1450 core with 2250 memory fully stable, doesn’t get over 70 degrees. I recently replaced the thermal pads with 1.5mm Artic thermal pads and paste with Artic MX-4. The GPU now idles around 28-30c with an ambient of 76 F. I play games and render movies and doesn't get over 60c at all. Really pleased minus the fan noise, may end up replacing them eventually. Key thing, if you do decide to replace the thermal pads or paste, it will be voiding the warranty from Gigabyte, however based on my experience with their RMA process, it took them over 2 months to replace my motherboard, even then, they sent it back with missing parts on the motherboard.

Reviews.title: I gave a "I like it" rating
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2017
Reviews.text:
I gave a "I like it" rating. I jumped ship from nvidea to amd just before the miners bough out the rx580s and jacked the price up. I was very happy with the price which was 270.

Coming from nvidea, these fans blow, and that's not a compliment. This is the loudest gpu I have ever heard! This is suppose to be for my bedroom not a damn server room! It would be funny if I didn't have to live with this! I've adjusted the fan speed but god damn, to get it to perform you want best to learn to live with the noise.

The performance is great so far. My GTX 960 could not handle mass effect andromeda. The cut scenes would chug! Once I upgraded to the rx580 I had no issues.

If you want great performance for a great price this is a great card, however the fans are a joke. I'd say up to $320 is a fair price.

Reviews.title: Perfect 1080p Card for Heavy Modders
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2019
Reviews.text:
With this card, I can crank up the settings and most games and still see 60fps-while this card is being bottlenecked by an fx 6300. The 8GB VRAM gives a lot of headroom for loading several graphics mods in games that can add up to using over 5GB or even 6.

However, the provided software is lacking, and the default fan curve is horrible-- not turning on until the card is already at 50C, and not scaling up very well at all. A custom fan curve is a must for this card. Depending on ambient temperatures and your case's cooling, you may also need to slightly underclock it.

Overall, a pretty good deal when gotten for $200 or less.

data.label: Coolerage T128010SU 75mm GTX1060 GTX1070 GTX1080 Graphics Card Fans for GIGABYTE AORUS GTX 1060 1070 1080 Ti G1 Gaming GV-N98T GTX 980 970 960 NTITANX GPU
data.description: Specification:

data.label: PNY NVIDIA Quadro K4200 Graphics Card VCQK4200-PB
data.description: The NVIDIA Quadro K4200 delivers incredible 3D application performance and capability, allowing you to take advantage of dual copy-engines for seamless data movement within GPU memory-all in a flexible, single-slot form factor. 4 GB of GDDR5 GPU memory with ultra-fast bandwidth is ideal for creating and rendering large, complex models. An all-new display engine drives up to four displays with Display Port 1.2 support for ultra-high resolutions like 3840 x 2160 at 60 Hz with 30-bit color. The Quadro K4200 is also fully compatible with NVIDIA Quadro Sync, which allows you to frame-lock multiple displays together, and also supports NVIDIA's SDI input and output boards for broadcast or digital cinema production workflows.

Reviews.title: Card works fine but I can't say the same for the adapter
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2021
Reviews.text: The video card works fine, but the same did not happen with the adapter which is useless.

Reviews.title: Solid GPU. Light weight, cool running under loads, stable!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2014
Reviews.text:
I built a video editing computer according to specs I read on a tech website. It called for both a Quadro K4000 GPU (not this K4200) and a GeForce GTX780. The idea was that the GeForce provided the superior rendering performance while the Quadro K4000 provided the stability and 10-bit processing for color adjustments and grading. The Quadro is the recommended board by Adobe for serious editing work.To be honest, I saw no difference whether the Quadro was installed or not, but it's impossible to tell what's really going on under the hood.

I became concerned because someone at PNY told me that they did not recommend nor support the two GPUs be installed in that configuration. I returned the K4000 because I could not justify the price tag for no discernible results.

Then, I decided to build another computer for a different purpose and at the time this Quadro K4200 was released. I must say that both the Quadro K4000 and the K4200 perform well. Unlike the GTX780, the Quadro is much smaller, lighter, and stays cooler under loads. Its size and weight helps because I'm building a portable system. And of course I prefer the 1 GB increase in VRAM over the K4000.

Reviews.title: nice card, smells good, no bling looks very professional
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2015
Reviews.text:
Seems snappy and quick and smells good (like electronics) coming out of the package. But this is only from what lititle I've used it. I've read that a lot of motherboards prior to a certain date are not sli capable, but mine is however my intention to use this card in the short term and potentially longterm in an sli configuration under kvm with vfio/vga pass through to a virtual machine may not fair well.. I hope I don't have to dual boot to get the "full bla bla bla quadro experience" plus if you trust the fanatical benchmarks on the Web the gtx980 is supposedly faster but I like this one it's slim, feels well built has good video connectors and promises of resolution that I can't stand to compromise with.

Doesn't seem to run very hot either... we'll see.

Reviews.title: I think it is a design flaw in the K4200 and would not recommend them to anyone that has long projects
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2015
Reviews.text: This is the second Quadro K4200 that I've purchased. The first one I returned, this one I should return. They ran for a only two days under long load before they caused my PC to freeze. In other words, I tried two different cards in three different Dell work stations and after a day or so they freeze the computers after about 40 minutes of GPU run time. I would restart the computer and the system would freeze again 30 or 40 minutes later. I spoke to PNY and they have no explanation or suggestions as to why this happens. I think it is a design flaw in the K4200 and would not recommend them to anyone that has long projects. They just freeze the computer and once in a while cause errors on the hard drives. My drives are mirrored so just a bit of recovery time lost and of course the project. If your drives aren't mirrored, you may be down for some time. What good is a card that freezes your computer after 40 minutes? I have run a pair of K2200, K620, a GTX 980, and a GTX 960 in these systems on with the same work load for weeks without any problems. I monitor temperature and they were well within operating range. The GPU load was 50-60%. No obvious reason to fail. They just do not seem to run long. I am disappointed because while they are running, they do a good job and take they only one card slot.

Reviews.title: Renders a faster viewport and playblast on Autodesk Maya 2015 but...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2015
Reviews.text: The card works great, renders a faster viewport and playblast on maya 2015 with a heavy load. The only downside is that PNY sent me a displayport to DVI-D adapter, and a DVI-I to VGA and they wont fit together. I spent a whole day looking for a displayport adapter in my area without results. All because of a packaging mistake I believe.

Reviews.title: Works great so far.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
Reviews.text: Brand name. Well supported. Still a great product even though it’s an older generation. Low energy consumption so it seems to run cool at least for my purposes.

Reviews.title: Not much to say about these cards yet. They ...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2014
Reviews.text: Not much to say about these cards yet. They arrived when they were supposed to and were in the condition they were supposed to be. I was moving up from (2) 600's to these 4200's so my 3D stuff is a lot clearer and faster. Google earth is a lot faster and more detailed as well.

Reviews.title: Excellent for Citrix VDI
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2015
Reviews.text:
Great cards at a good price.
You can shop around and find quite a variation in price on these 4200 cards.
We use with Citrix XenApp in a HP server for dedicated high end OpenGL apps. Work great with the right combination of XenServer, XenDesktop.
Very high performance for CAD/CAM.

Reviews.title: Solid workstation performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2015
Reviews.text: I bought two for my new Dual ten core Xeon workstation. For some reason I never could get them into SLI mode. Never mind I want them separate anyway. I don't play games. One for each monitor. A 30" Apple Cinema and my Wacom Cintiq 24HD. Photoshop flies, Lightroom is heaven.

Reviews.title: Best quadro for the price
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2014
Reviews.text: Best quadro for the price! It is a workhorse. Not the fastest GPU but I can run it hard 6 days a week and it just doesn't fail. Great pro video card card for premiere cc.

data.label: MSI GAMING GeForce RTX 2070 8GB GDRR6 256-bit HDMI/DP/USB Ray Tracing Turing Architecture HDCP Graphics Card (RTX 2070 GAMING Z 8G)
data.description: NVIDIA Turing Architecture. This revolutionary architecture, combined with our all-new GeForce RTX platform, fuses together real-time ray tracing, artificial intelligence, and programmable shading. You've never created and enjoyed games like this before. Ray tracing is the definitive solution for lifelike lighting, reflections, and shadows, offering a level of realism far beyond what's possible using traditional rendering techniques. NVIDIA Turing is the first GPU capable of real-time ray tracing. GeForce RTX gaming GPUs come loaded with next-generation GDDR6 memory, support for DirectX 12 features, and more. This is graphics reinvented.

Reviews.title: Great RTX Card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
Reviews.text:
(11/20/2018) I purchased the MSI RTX 2070 Gaming Z 8G. I took many factors and pricing based on what was available and compared to other cards. I was primarily looking for a card to replace my ASUS GTX 970 Turbo. With Battlefield 5 releasing and testing my setup (below) with the GTX 970, my settings could only handle 60 FPS with everything at medium. Battlefield 1, I was able to play at around 80 FPS with DX12 off, so it was definitely time to upgrade.

My Setup:
CPU: Intel Core i7 7700k at 4.2 GHz
RAM: 16 GB Vengance
Motherboard: ASUS Strix B250G Gaming
Monitor: ASUS MG278Q (2K res at 144 Hz)

Upon receiving the card, the card is definitely bigger than the GTX 970 and heavier. Make sure you have enough room in your case as this card extends the micro ATX board setup. The card come with plates and can customize the RGB LED's.

I chose this card as it was par with the RTX 2080 in cores and clock speeds, and even the GTX 1080. The downfall which many will know is that RAY tracing is not amazing with this card. I play all my games in 2k res at 144Hz and really only enjoy playing FPS at or above 60 FPS. Playing BF5 with ray tracing on (low) with everything at ultra had around 20 to 30 FPS average with sometimes reaching mid 50's. Once i reduced my graphics to high instead of ultra, FPS gains were up 10 to 20 FPS. With Ray tracing off and everything on ultra, I was getting anywhere between 80 to 130 FPS. Changing my res to 1080 with everything on ultra and even RAY tracing on ultra I had FPS above 60. The downfall to this was quality of the game graphics.

As of 12/13/2018, EA/Nvidia release patches that improved the FPS with RAY tracing, but only a gain of about 10 FPS. I still continue to play BF5 with RAY tracing off and everything on ultra. I did notice some hiccups where the game would freeze for a split of a millisecond, but it could be the game more than the card as BF5 is still buggy.

As of 4/4/2019 this card continues to perform perfectly with any game I throw at it. I currently have been playing anthem with above 50 FPS with the new ray tracing features and DLSS available in the game. There are some dips due to high fidelity and other high graphical areas within a battle area, which is why the lowest I have seen is 50 FPS. With Ray tracing turned off, i get above 70 FPS. While this card is big, I am hoping to replace the stock fan with a water loop system. On a micro ATX board, do not expect to utilize any of the PCI lanes besides the one for the GPU.

Overall, I am very happy with this upgrade for the price. The 1080 ti stock is basically depleted or costs over $1000. The 2080 cards are better than the stock 2070 cards, but this msi card is par or better than the 2080 stock cards. Only advantage to the 2080 cards was more CUDA cores. This is my first msi card as well, since i usually go with EVGA or ASUS. EVGA unfortunately did not have any in stock during the time of my purchase.

Reviews.title: Easy to install, made out of quality materials, software easy to use and overclock.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2019
Reviews.text:
Unboxing: Unboxing you get many papers; consisting of a Quickstart guide, a couple pieces of paper telling me how to register my GPU, a set of paper coasters (because MSI), the GPU itself inside of a very protective Styrofoam casing, along with a support bracket.

Installation: As I was replacing my old GTX 1070 ti, all I had to do was follow the, if somewhat cartoonish yet very helpful and straightforward installation guide. You need to undo the screws holding in the current GPU on the back of the case, then unclip the little buckle at the end of the PCIE express connector. Once that's done, you unplug the current GPU and remove it. Then, all you need to do is take your new GPU and push it from the back to the front until you hear a satisfying click. At which point you use the screws you took out at the beginning to screw it into place. Once this is done, you plug in the 6 and 8 pin connectors into the GPU. When you turn on the PC, it may start up with its default resolution, which for me, was this blurry 600 x 800. But once I went to Nvidia's driver page and installed the proper driver along with geforce experience, it was only a matter of time (no more than 20 minutes) to get the drivers installed and working perfectly. Once I got the drivers installed I just restarted by pc just incase. Once that was done, I installed MSI Afterburner to overclock. The best overclock I could get was 100mhz on both the core clock and memory, which was pretty good. It's important to note that I did not need to install the support bracket, so I can't say whether or not if it was easy to install.

Performance: The performance of this chip is much better than the GTX 1070 ti I was replacing, and rivals something like Nvidia's own GTX 1080. While I wasn't able to take full advantage of RTX ray tracing, I was able to fully max out Far Cry 5 on 2560 x 1080 and get 90+ frames with little to no fan noise. I also fully maxed out GTA V and, while it was a mixed bag of frame rates, I always stayed above 60 fps and never went beyond 75 degrees. Because of the massive heatsink on this GPU, the fans only speed up when the temperature is sustained at around 60+ degrees. The RGB lighting is pretty, but somewhat understated, and by no means should it be the deciding factor between this and another GPU of the same caliber.

Conclusion: Overall, this is a very nice GPU with subtle, yet pretty RGB and had great temps and performance all the way round. While it is one of the more larger GPU heatsinks I've seen, both in width and length, as I've said, its able to manage the RTX 2070 quietly and effectively. As a first time PC builder, this was incredibly easy to install and setup, and would recommend for someone who wants RTX power, but at a reasonable price to performance ratio.

Reviews.title: Quality Gaming GPU - Smooth Performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
Reviews.text: This was my first “Gaming” PC build (it’s for my teenage son) and the GPU was the last component we needed to complete the build. After a great deal of research and consideration, we ended up choosing the MSI RTX 2070 Gaming Z. Our motherboard is a MSI MPG Z390 Gaming Pro Carbon AC, so we decided to maintain consistency and stick with one of MSI’s offerings. The MSI RTX 2070 Gaming Z is a mid to upper level GPU, both in performance and price. The Ray Tracing capability (RTX) is not widely supported at this time by game creators, however it should be more widely utilized in the next year or two. Nvidia recently released the GTX 1660 and GTX 1660 Ti, which seems to be their attempt at providing a more affordable alternative however it does not support Ray Tracing, it has less CUDA cores, and it also has less memory. We opted for the RTX 2070 Gaming Z because it should be a little more “future-proof” and provide good, steady, and stable performance without the need to upgrade as soon. So far, the GPU is performing flawlessly! Super easy installation and setup. The RGB LEDs look cool and it is amazingly quiet during operation. The MSI RTX 2070 Gaming Z is factory overclocked so I would recommend downloading and using MSI’s Afterburner software (free from MSI website) to monitor and adjust the GPU performance. Seems like a great product so far!

Reviews.title: So smooth!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019
Reviews.text:
I was a little nervous as the first runs of the RTX 2070 had a lot of failures and DOA's. I've had this one for one month now and have not had one problem. It runs 1920 MHz right out of the box without overclocking.

I was lucky to get in when it was in inventory and being sold by Amazon instead having to pay extra from someone else.

Pros:
Fast out of the box.
You can overclock it, but I didn't want to take any chances for a small gain.
Quiet!
RGB LED's.
8GB. It will handle large textures.

Cons:
A FOOT long. Measure your case. For the moment I have to removed the drive cage to fit it in. I'll get a new case soon. Maybe not really a con as I miss read the length. It was in metric and I converted wrong.
Price, but you already know that.
So no real cons.

TLDR; Buy if you don't want to spend over a grand for a GTX 1080 TI or a RTX 2080/2080 TI. A better buy might be a RTX 2060 6GB if you don't care about fast ray tracing or large textures.

Reviews.title: Amazing Card with Minor Noise Issue
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
Reviews.text:
Runs great, absolutely no issues playing AAA games with Maxed Out (Ultra) settings with 60+ FPS on a 1440p screen with minimal (~1ms avg.) response time. Only complaint is that there is a minor noise issue with the card I received: when the card has a full load, it starts to make a rattling noise of approximately 35dB which, believe me, I found incredibly annoying when I was playing (for example) The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt and there was little background noise.

Overall great buy for the price but know that it doesn't come without a few flaws, of course!

Pros:
- Runs AMAZINGLY well
- Able to overclock it to 2100MHz
- Never below 60FPS on 1440p IPS
- Price (compared to a GTX 1080 ti, they have perform similarly)

Cons:
- Minor noise issue (mentioned above)
- Wish there was more RGB lighting
- RBG lighting's "Music mode" was a bit slow to match the beat of my tracks

Reviews.title: runs black ops 4 great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2018
Reviews.text:
I love this card, its a bit pricier than some other 2070's but it has a little more power and cool RGB lighting that is not overly bright, it just adds to the case lighting already. It runs black ops 4 great in combination with an ryzen 2600x 90-140fps on average (in blackout mode, way higher in normal game modes). Only thing is the support bar doesn't really fit in my PC, but too lazy to take it out.

edit: its now feb-17-2019 card is still fine, runs most games great.
COD blackout has performance issues specifically takes maximum prerendered frames and some tweaking to work great but it will, hopefully future game patches fix issues.
For other games again. Still running great.

edit2: 6-14-19 If you read above, support bar didnt fit. Well I finally had to manage the video cards sag was leaning on the slot pretty hard. Card still working great though. Especially after I fixed the sag. So warning to those who had trouble getting the bar in, around the 8month mark the card will start sagging.

Reviews.title: Good But Deeply Flawed Card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2019
Reviews.text:
Bought this card a couple of months ago for a birthday/Christmas present. The card put out a lot of heat but that was expected and it ran great until February. I usually boot up my computer in the morning and use it off and on until I shut it down before bed. I walked in and turned the screen on and nothing! I checked the computer was still on but again nothing on the screen. I shut the computer down pulled the side off and restarted. I got a bios error B2 indicating something was wrong with my video card. I pulled it out reseated it and again the same bios error. I put my old card it and it worked fine.
Requested an RMA from MSI got it and spend $22 on shipping a card a little under 2 months old to them for repair/replacement (Shouldn't have had to do this). MSI received the card and is shipping me a refurb. I don't have it yet and will update this review when I do.
This card when working is great! But I'd stay away from the RTX 2000's until NVidia gets its act together. I just wish there was a viable alternative!

Well the card MSI sent back was bad and had to be sent back. It started showing artifacts the second day. It seemed to correct the problem by the fourth day the artifacts were back and it continued to go down hill from there until nothing would correct the problem. I used Display Driver Uninstaller and everything else I could come up with. Nothing worked! Called MSI this time and they paid to have it sent back to them and they are shipping out another card today (3-13-19). There is no reason that this card shouldn't have been checked before they sent it out. Very poor quality control on MSI's part. Until now I've never had any trouble with any MSI part but this is enough for me. I also lowered my rating to 1 star because the second card was bad, too.

Reviews.title: Gets the job done for a 2k card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2019
Reviews.text:
So far I haven't had any issues with any games that I've run with this card. At least any that had anything to do with the gpu itself and more to do with how tuned the games themselves were. Naturally haven't had the opportunity to try out any of the features of the rtx card, but considering I've been getting good fps on all my games along the 2k range I would say it'll help out even more with games that do take advantage of the rtx's additional features.

Naturally though it does count itself to be a 4k card that is mostly going to be dependent on the game itself. Older titles that allow 4k your going to be quite at home but with the newer titles its more a fluid run to go for the 2k marker unless you can cut back on some of the settings.

Reviews.title: Great for Overclocking and 2020 PC Gaming!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this back in 2019 when I built my first gaming/work desktop PC. I have had great success with this graphics card and learned how to overclock later in the same year. Upon overclocking, I found my overall performance increase noticeably. I use a custom fan curve and it keeps temps at around 60C during high loads and the noise is not an issue at all.

Highly recommend this GPU for those in the upper-mid price range.

Reviews.title: Works as you would like it to
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020

Reviews.title: Confusing labeling lead to misfit product
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2021
Reviews.text:
This product is labeled as being for ATI Nvidia Graphics cards. I bought it to fit an old low-profile AMD Radeon HD 7500 into a standard sized slot on an old computer. It worked for the DVI port but covered the HDMI port.

Admittedly, maybe it's my mistake so I'm giving three stars instead of one but I also believe the labeling is confusing. It took me a bit of research to refresh my memory but ATI used to be an independent entity which produced GPUs but was subsequently bought by AMD about 10 years ago which continued to make cards using the ATI name for several years afterwards. Thus, the label ATI Nvidia graphics card is not really enough to go on when deciding if this card will fit.

Since it's so inexpensive though, I'm just using it as is and sticking to the DVI port which isn't my first choice but so is life. I'll make it hopefully. Anyway, maybe somebody with a similar card will avoid making the wrong purchase after reading my review although I note there aren't that many of this kind of adapter available for some reason so... in a pinch, it still sort of works... thus, 3 stars.

Reviews.title: Good compromise
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2014
Reviews.text:
I installed this card on my regular "office" desktop computer and the V3900 on my dedicated CAD computer. The V3900 card pushed my WIndows Experience Index for graphics and for gaming up to 6.8.

The V3800 pushed my office computer WIndows graphics score up to 5.8 and gaming graphics up to 6.3 from about a 3.5 score.

While not as eye-popping as the graphics on my CAD computer, the 2.3-2.8 increase in graphics performance is significant, and the V3800 is somewhat less cost than the V3900 but about half the power consumption. Since I use my office computer a LOT, I opted for lower power consumption solution because I really don't need the high-power graphics.

Reviews.title: Zotac Gaming PC Runs Perfectly w/ No Lagging, Fast Boot Times, 300 FPS for CS:GO-Good Value
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2019
Reviews.text:
I bought the Zotac MEK Ultra Gaming PC two months ago for my teen after his brand name computer that was 8 years old was just too outdated to justify the cost of further upgrades. I was hesitant as I hadn’t heard of Zotac PCs and didn’t see any reviews on Amazon of the Zotac PC (only Zotac parts). But my teen researched and found some good comments elsewhere, and the Zotac PC had all the specs he wanted without the huge premium I’d pay to get the same specs in a big name PC. While I can’t yet address how the Zotac PC will perform in the long run or tech support (none needed yet), so far it runs perfectly for gaming and general applications.

I do recall an initial hiccup because the HDD wasn’t initialized, so it seemed like the PC only had an SSD. My teen did some quick online research, and it was a simple fix (that didn’t require any physical alteration) where I recall he just had to initialize the HDD. There haven’t been any other issues. He has no lagging and gets really fast boot times due to the SSD and lack of bloatware. His favorite game is CS:GO, and that’s what he plays the most. CS:GO runs great and is always smooth regardless of the map, and he’s always sitting at 300 FPS (he caps it there for less strain and fluctuation). The Zotac PC was an excellent value at $1419, has good specs and is a pleasure for gaming. Will update if any issues arise. 5 stars.

Reviews.title: Seems like a luck of the draw, buyer beware.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2019
Reviews.text:
For reference purposes I am running:

Corsair Carbide 500R case
ASRock Z170 Gaming mainboard
2x 8GB Corsair Vengeance LPX DDR4 2133
Core i5 6600k with one of those sweet/ugly Noctua heat sinks
Corsair AX850 PSU
Old GPU: MSI Gaming GTX 770

No manual overclocks or anything fancy, I just like things to run smooth and quiet.

—-

(Note that if you do want this card be sure you have the room to spare in your case, it’s beastly, but solid at the very least, the shroud around the card is nice sturdy metal.)

Amazon had a pretty good deal going on these Zotac 2070s so I figured I’d give it a shot as a number of third party review sites claimed the AMP Extreme to be the card to get performance wise, among the 2070 series at any rate. Got the first card and the install was quite smooth and while I had things apart this gave me an opportunity to clean up some of the wiring in my case and get rid of some dust build up.

Card ran great, fired up Witcher 3 and decided to break the card in by maxing out the settings. FPS was between 110-130 FPS @ 1080p so all seemed well. About 8 hours or so into the game I started getting weird bloom effects and artifacting. Started paring down some settings but the crashes continued.

I was pretty sure it wasn’t the game despite W3 being known for annoying crashes (I had previously played through the entirety of the game a year and a half ago on the old MSI 770) but I started going through some of the various fixes for the game anyways.

A few hours later and I was testing the card itself since nothing was fixing my issues. I used HWMonitor to check temps and voltages and then ran Heaven Benchmark. The card got through the Basic test okay but temps were high. Running the Extreme test caused the program to crash and the card to hit north of 70° C each of three separate times.

I tried playing some less graphically intense games such as Stellaris and Subnautica but was still having performance problems. I decided I didn’t want to play around with the card any longer and returned it for replacement. The new card hardly made it into windows after boot up before it had issues, reinstalled it and tried again but kept getting major artifacting and screen tears.

After this I’m done with Zotac. I reinstalled my MSI (without incident, I might add) and will give the 2070 another shot from a different manufacturer.

Reviews.title: Great bang for buck, better than past generations!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2018
Reviews.text:
Why I bought:
Built a new small form factor gaming PC inside a Fractal Design Node 202 and picked up this blower style card to exhaust heat mostly.

Performance:
With two low noise adapted intake case fans over the card and with my hardware monitor up playing demanding games such as Assassin’s Creed Odyssey on Max settings in 1440p the card barely reaches 68C, averages 70-80FPS, and the fan almost never spins as the case intakes do more than enough to cool.

Conclusion:
Got it on sale and paid $470, which I’ll admit is less than I’ve spent before (paid $650 for a 980 Ti few years ago), and it performs significantly better than past cards in the same price range! If you have the budget, this card will not let you down for the price and blows past generations away even without the new RTX-specific features! Great for 1440p and higher frame rates!

Reviews.title: RTX Looks Amazing in Shadow of the Tomb Raider
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2018
Reviews.text: The lighting was dramatically better than any I had ever seen in game when I was playing Shadow of the Tomb Raider. Downloading BattlefieldV now, so I have not seen it yet. This card operates on the upper edge of what its safe thermal limit is in my case, which is admittedly not great when it comes to airflow and why i wanted a blower card to exhaust the hot air rather than recirculate it in the case. Still, it's is solidly in the safe zone, and for all I know the fan would spin up even more if it had to. It certainly isn't silent when you are putting it through its paces though. But at this price, you can barely get a 1080 or 1070ti. To see a 2070 as an option was great, so I snatched this up, and I am glad I did.

Reviews.title: Baller card, unfortunate that it's being scalped
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2018
Reviews.text:
I got this card a couple years back. I initially had problems with it resynchronizing and flickering. Turned out to be cheap display port cables. Once I got decent cables it's worked great. Currently have it undervolted and overclocked a little running at 987mv, +75 core clock, +200 memory clock, at 63C under full load.

It's unfortunate that the cards are now being scalped at almost double what I bought it for back in 2018. I personally would not buy from a scalper unless my PC was dead in the water and I had to get one for it to function. Give it some time, they'll be available again soon.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
Reviews.text: Cleanly and carefully installed, and it didn't work from the minute I put it in. I would launch a game, it would fully load, you'd spawn in and it would work for a minute then crash. I thought it was the other hardware in my computer, so I updated all my drivers and still nothing worked. After crashing, the whole computer basically crashes and you have to force a shut down to get your computer back to normal (the screen goes black with artifacts). Called the "expert" on the order invoice page and after I explained to him the situation, he told me send it back and I told him he had to send me a new one. Really disappointed and annoyed since it was so expensive and seemed to run games pretty well. As a test, I ran Fortnite on high settings @ 1440p and it was able to keep up with 144fps at about 50% load. Again, just disappointed and annoyed that for the money, you don't get what you pay for.

Reviews.title: DVI-D didn't work, performance great then suddenly not
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this card because it was the only one of the RX 5*** generation to have a DVI-D port. I have a DVI-D only monitor that I used with an older RX 480. DVI-D on this RX 5500 failed to drive the monitor. For this reason I returned the card.

As a separate test it did work over HDMI to a small monitor. It worked great in a 30 minute 3D test, but inexplicably it would subsequently operate at half speed. The case has extra cooling and ambient temperature is low so I don't have any reason to think it was thermal throttling. This may have been fixable with settings or something but I didn't test the card long enough to figure out if it was possible.

Undeniably good thing about this card: It was remarkably quiet.

Reviews.title: Lights always on? Didn't work with waterblock?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
Reviews.text:
The GPU is a 2080, so you know it is going to be a good performer. I know lots of people dislike the blower style fan design, but I actually like it since it exhausts all of the hot air out the back rather than swirling it around inside the case. But I have two issues with it.

First, I could not find a way to control a row of annoying LEDs; they were on all the time and, worse, were a multicolored pastel. I searched for software to control these but couldn't find anything on either the ASUS or Nvidia websites. I ended up removing the cooler, pulling the LED power cable from the connector, and reassembling. That at least turned off these LEDs.

The second problem I had was when I tried to install a Corsair XG7 RGB GPU waterblock. It physically fit on, but the card would not work, no output to the monitor, not even during boot. I don't know for sure, but I think the card checks to see if the fan is working and shuts down if one is not plugged in. Which was a bummer. I ended up draining my loop, removing the GPU waterblock, and reinstalling the original blower cooler. Thankfully the blower is pretty quiet after setting it to Silent Mode with the GPU Tweak II software.

A versão com conector tem um desempenho melhor em virtude do clock base ser maior, enquanto versão sem conector tem o clock base inferior. Mas a questão é como identificar a que tem o conector de 6 pinos da que não tem. A versão com 6 pinos(melhor que a que não tem) tem na descrição P: gtx 1650 tuf P gaming(conforme a imagem) enquanto a outra não tem o P na descrição: gtx 1650 tuf gaming. Tive as duas e troquei e estou deixando a dica porque antes eu não sabia como identificar e entrei em contato com a Asus e agora estou compartilhando.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.title: Works Great. No Extra Power Needed.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
Reviews.text: I needed a low profile video card for a small form factor computer that didn't require it's own power source, and didn't cost a fortune. This one fit all 3 requirements. It was a simple install and the software was easy to find and download.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hab wirklich lange und intensiv nach einer neuen, bezahlbaren und vom Preis nicht so abgehobenen Grafikkarte gesucht. Hier passt das Preis/Leistungsverhältnis für mich gerade noch so. Wir zocken wenig wenn dann Strategiespiele, Autorennen usw eine unserer Anforderungen war die Grafik entscheidend zu verbessern ohne Unmengen Geld zu investieren. Also neuer Monitor, Grafikkarte und ein zusätzlicher Speicherblock. Das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen!!!
Kein geruckel mehr und eine schön saubere Grafik, das beste die Grafikkarte wird bei uns nicht mal warm, läuft also alles sauber. Für 160€ kann man bei der Karte nichts verkehrt machen!

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Spain on August 27, 2022
Reviews.text: Precio un pelin subido pero viendo lo que hay pues no esta mal se defiende bien con juegos como the witcher 3 asi que a mi me vale.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 3, 2022
Reviews.text:

Leichter Einbau. Mußte nur den Halter von groß auf kleine umbauen. War im Paket.
Schnelle Karte, läuft unter Windows 11 hervorragend.
Preis Leistung ist gut.

It took me half a day to get the actual Nvidia drivers do run with win11. It seems to run okish now but I'm having problems with the video im working on that i didn't have before with the old card.

Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
Reviews.text: Some of the previous reviewers had opined that there cards might have been returns. I received an open box (no factory tape on the folds) and no documentation on the inside. No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.title: Calling all base model alien ware x51 users
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2021
Reviews.text: Okay so to start , can you run gears 5 on 4k absolutely not. Can you run in a stock Alienware x51 without upgrading your power brick and running extra power ? Absolutely yes! Fits right in slim designed case , total install time was 10 min if that. I have looked high and I've looked low for a form fitting card for the x51 without a massive power overhaul. This card is not what I call "gaming" ready but the price point should sell you that. Overall it's slim will definitely fit in a modular case and does the trick of you are looking to do anything that's graphic hungry. Minus of course Fortnite at 60fps consistent. The value is peek. The extra 2gb of room helps to. Hope this is your final review to read before pulling the trigger. I did , great product in an oversaturated market currently

Reviews.title: Perfect for the price in today's market!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2022
Reviews.text: This GPU isn't the top of the line, but paired with my 60hz 2560x1600 HP monitor, it's given me crystal clear images with good FPS in Halo Infinite (@1366x768 for H.I. only), Kerbal Space Program, and Automation, the Car Company Tycoon Game. Though in Beam.NG, visual settings have to be set to Low for decent-good FPS. It keeps at a decent temperature (35-45°C) while being run at 100% consistently. If you're looking for a good GPU for 3D dense programs such as Second Life, this one is more then capable with the sacrifice of FPS (25-30 at High, 10-15 at Ultra graphics settings).

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Brazil on December 11, 2021
Reviews.text: Não sou nenhum expert, mas o motivo dessa avaliação é deixar uma dica preciosa: diferença entre a placa com conector 6 pinos X a sem conector. A versão com conector tem um desempenho melhor em virtude do clock base ser maior, enquanto versão sem conector tem o clock base inferior. Mas a questão é como identificar a que tem o conector de 6 pinos da que não tem. A versão com 6 pinos(melhor que a que não tem) tem na descrição P: gtx 1650 tuf P gaming(conforme a imagem) enquanto a outra não tem o P na descrição: gtx 1650 tuf gaming. Tive as duas e troquei e estou deixando a dica porque antes eu não sabia como identificar e entrei em contato com a Asus e agora estou compartilhando.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on May 14, 2017
Reviews.text:
Die Palit GTX 1050 Ti KalmX 4GB ersetzt hier eine eine ebenfalls empfehlenswerte passive Asus GTX 750 2GB.
Die Karte ist wirklich lautlos, also auch keine elektronischen Störgeräusche wie Spulenfiepen unter Last.

Die 3D Leistung ist grob gesagt doppelt so hoch wie die der GTX750, bei minimal höherem Stromverbrauch unter Last.
Um die 3D Leistung, die hier lautlos und passiv gekühlt geliefert wird, einzuordnen:
Überhalb einer AMD 460, in etwa das Niveau einer GTX680, unterhalb einer AMD 470. Auf Youtube gibt es anschauliche Vergleichsvideos, in welchem man bspw 1050ti gegen GTX680 usw selber ansehen kann.

Die Karte treibt hier 2 Displays, eines davon UDH 3840*2160, und ältere bzw. weniger anspruchsvolle Titel wie WoW/WoT usw laufen mit angepassten&reduzierten Einstellungen auch auf 3840*2160 problemlos mit 60fps, bei um die 60-70% Auslastung der Karte.

Thema 4K - die Karte bietet HDCP 2.2, und mit den derzeitigen Betatreibern stellt Netflix auch schon 4K dar - inklusive hardwarebeschleunigtem H265. wenn man also einen lautlosen MediaPC mit 4K plant - ein wichtiger Vorteil, da Nvidias ältere Karten (9er, 8er, 7er Serie) kein 4K bei Netflix unterstützen.

Die Karte bietet 3 gleichzeitig nutzbare Anschlüsse, 1* Display Port, 1* DL-DVI, 1* HDMI, inklusive digitalem Surround-Ton auf HDMI&DP.

Die Abmessungen von 182*142mm Länge*Höhe bei eingehaltener Breite von 2 Slots sind in Mini-Gehäusen wie dem Fractal Design Core 500 problemlos, allerdings sollte man bei ULTRAULTRAkompakten mini-ITX Gehäusen vorher prüfen, ob die 142mm Höhe passen.

Die passive Kühlung läuft gut und reicht aus - bei Film & Video, Desktop & Browsen im Bereich 40 Grad. Auch bei typischer mittlerer 3D-Spiele Last wie WoW bleibt alles im grünen Bereich, da ist die Karte nach einer Stunde 4K mit 60 fps im 60 Grad-Bereich, alles komplett Lüfter&lautlos. Das ganze im für passiv gekühlte Systeme mit etwas mehr Anspruch sehr gut geeignetem Fractal Design Core 500 Gehäuse, in welchem die Karte senkrecht steht und alleine schon durch ihre Eigenkonvenktion einen guten Luftfluss erzeugt - und von unten, Seiten und nach oben gut Luft bekommt bzw abgeben kann. In einem *geschlossenem* oder *sehr engem* Mini-Gehäuse allerdings könnte das problematischer werden.

Unter konstanter & totaler Volllast, getestet mit synthetischer Folter-Last mittels "Furmark", ohne jeglichen Lüfter irgendwo im Gehäuse, kann man sie ins thermische Limit kriegen, das bei etwa 83 Grad erreicht wird. Die Karte stürzt dann nicht ab oder überhitzt gnadenlos, sie stellt dann "nur" noch den normalen 1290Mhz Takt zur Verfügung, den beschleunigte 1392Mhz Boosttakt nicht mehr und geht ggf. sogar nach längerer Zeit auf um die 1.1Ghz runter um nicht zu überhitzen. Anders als die GPU und die Spannungswandler sind die RAM-Speicherchips (Hersteller: Micron) geizigerweise nicht am Kühlkörper angekoppelt, und werden bedenklich heiss. Stabil und absturzfrei bleibt aber alles, allerdings dann eben nicht mehr auf maximalen / turbo-Tempo. Sobald auch nur ein superlangsam rotierender, unhörbar leiser (Netzteil)Lüfter mit 300 Umdrehungen im Gehäuse Luft zirkuliert, ist selbst unter solcher Horror-Last wie Furmark die Karte non-stop auf Vollgas und bleibt kühl genug.

Die Leistungsaufnahme, auch unter Volllast, bleibt bequem innerhalb der PCIe-Spezifikationen, sprich, man braucht keine zusätzlichen Stromversorgungskabel. Allerdings haben schwächere passiv gekühlte Karten wie die GTX750 oder AMD460 noch weniger Leistungsaufnahme unter Vollast, die Mehrleistung der GTX1050ti schlug beim Messen mit pi mal Daumen 10 Watt mehr zu Buche. Unter normaler Last, wie Desktop, Video, nicht maxímal anspruchsvollen 3D Spielen hingegen ist die Leistungsaufnahme ähnlich bis gleich, bei 3D Spielen sogar teilweise etwas geringer, da dann die Nvidia750 oder AMD460 auf Volllast laufen und die 1050ti oft nur zu 60%-70% Last hast.

Der Lieferumfang ist knapp. Keine Kabel, keine Spiele oder Playersoftware, aber immerhin ein Softwaretool mit dem man Taktraten usw einstellen kann.

Fazit
prima:
++ völlig lautlos, auch keine elektronische Störgeräusche wie fiepende Spulen
++ voller 4K Support, inkl HDCP 2.2 mit 4K/UHD Unterstützung für Netflix & co
++ für passive Kühlung höchste 3D&2D-Performance im Markt (Stand Mai 2017), in etwa wie eine Geforce GTX680.
++ 3 Monitore/Fernseher/Projektoren ansteuerbar
++ HDMI, DP, DL-DVI
++ passiver Betrieb bei normaler Last ohne jeglichen Lüfter völlig problemlos, 40 Grad desktop, 60-70 Grad 3D/Spiele.
++ volle H265 Unterstützung in Hardware
++ 4GB Speicher

gut
+ saubere Surround-Sound Implementation auf HDMI/DP, allerdings keinerlei weitere Einstellmöglichkeiten ausser Windows.
+ keine weitere Stromversorgung nötig, PCIE reicht. Leistungsaufnahme unter Vollast allerdings eine Spur höher als AMD460 und GTX750
+ immerhin nicht nur 2 Jahre Gewährleistung, sondern volle Garantie, aber andere Hersteller bieten auch 3 oder 5 Jahre.
+ Karte stürzt auch unter synthetischer Horror-Vollast wie Furmark ohne jegliche Kühlung nicht ab, sondern hält sich selber im thermischen Limit, indem sie auf Basistakt bzw 1.1 Ghz geht.

solala
-+ Lieferumfang bietet zwar ein Tool zum Einstellen von Taktraten usw, aber sonst eben auch nicht mehr.

schlecht
- RAM Speicherchips sind nicht mit dem Kühlkörper verbunden und werden unter konstanter absoluter maximallast (wie furmark) ohne jegliche Lüftung dadurch knapp überhalb ihrer Herstellervorgaben erhitzt. Die 20-50 cent Einsparung bei der Herstellung für ein paar Wärmeleitpads&Baseplate sind geizig.

Einfach gesagt: Für lautlos/lüfterlos passiv gekühlte Systeme ist die Palit 1050ti Kalm Stand Mai 2017 - und auch auf absehbare Zeit - die stärkste Grafikkarte im Markt. Die 3D Leistung ist dabei bequem auf dem Level von nicht all zu alten einstigen Flagschiffen wie der Nvidia GTX680. Weiterhin ermöglicht sie 4K Netflix und co (derzeit allerdings noch mit Betatreibern, die aber stabil liefen), was sonst kaum Grafikkarten erlauben, und auch weniger leistungshungrige Spiele (wie WoW) laufen mit etwas runtergedrehter Güte selbst bei nur 60-70% Grafikkartenlast auf 4K mit 60fps.

Wenn noch mehr, nonstop, 100% maximale 3D Last, 24 Stunden 7 Tage die Woche geplant ist, bspw. als lautloser Numbercruncher, non-stop-video-encoder oder Renderknecht - würde ich persönlich allerdings irgendwo im Gehäuse (und sei es Netzteil) einen ultralangsam rotierenden, und unhörbaren grossen Lüfter montieren - da Palit die RAM-Chips nicht mit dem Kühlkörper verbunden hat und die wenn auch stabil, doch sehr heiss sind und zudem die Karte ohne jeglichen Luftstrom unter Horrorlast den Turbotakt nicht einsetzt um nicht zu überhitzen. Ich habe das (im für passive Systeme sehr zu empfehlenden Fractal Design Core 500) ganz einfach gelöst: Das hat einen großen und bei langsamer Drehung unhörbar leisen Lüfter, der aus ist. Ich habe den auf dem Mainboard (Asus) so eingestellt, dass dieser bei 75 Grad anläuft. Nach einer Woche Betrieb, darunter auch nächtelang Dauerlast als Videoencoder ist das nicht einmal passiert. Wenn ich allerdings Horrortests a la Furmark anwerfe, setzt er sich nach einiger Zeit in Bewegung, aus 1 Meter Abstand unhörbar, und die Karte bleibt auf Vollgas & kühl. Somit ist die Sicherheit gegeben, dass auch im Hochsommer nichts überhitzt, und ansonsten 100% lüfter&lautlos.

Wegen den eingesparten Wärmepads am RAM-Speicher würde ich eigentlich nur 4 Sterne geben, aber: Das ist schon sehr theoretische Kritik, und man kriegt im Alltag die stärkste lautlose Video & 3D Karte, in allen normalen Szenarien inkl. nicht maximal leistungshungriger Spiele problemlos zu kühlen, mit vergleichweise sparsamer Leistungsaufnahme - ideal für Home-entertainment PCs, auch mit Netflix 4K, genug 3D Power auch für viele Spiele (in FHD sowieso), H265 in Hardware, selbst 3D-Anwendungen kann man gut nutzen, 4GB RAM und sobald auch nur ein schwacher Luftzug (Netzteillüfter?) herrscht ist alles im tiefgrünen Bereich? Also da kann ich nicht abwerten und vergebe volle 5 Sterne.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on November 17, 2021
Reviews.text:
使用構成：Ryzen 5 3500、Radeon RX 580、550W電源、DDR4-2666 8GB×2

選んだ理由は2020年夏時点で10万円クラスの自作PCを作りたく、一番コスパが良いグラボを探していたからです。購入当時は1.9万と2万円以下でしたので、NVIDIAの同性能グラボのGTX 1650 Super(当時は2.5万円くらい？)より安く、購入しました。

欠点としては、消費電力の公称値が高いことと、高負荷時のファンの音が大きいことくらいです。冬場は暖房と一緒に稼働させるとブレーカーがよく落ちました(笑)←ボロアパートなのでコンセントプラグが2箇所しかなく、容量を一気に突破した可能性が高いです。

一応上記構成で3つゲーム出来ましたのでfps値載せます。
Dead by Daylight : 60fps張り付き(fps上限が60のゲームなので、それ以上は分かりません)
原神 : 60fps張り付き(fps上限が60のゲームなので、それ以上は分かりません)
APEX Legends : 100〜140fps(中画質設定)

ゲーム中のファンの音はかなり大きいので、プレイ中はイヤフォン又はヘッドセット必須です。ただ、VC相手によるとファンの音自体はVCに載っていない様なので、うるさすぎるわけでもなさそうです。

ゲーム用途以外では、基本的に静音です。動画編集はしていませんが、ゲーム中よりはマシだと思います(他レビューを参考にしてください)。

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Japan on July 3, 2021
Reviews.text:
GTX１０５０　４Gからこちらに交換
まともなGPUでRadeonを使うのは初だったのですがドライバー？ソフトウェア？がNVIDIAと比べ結構不安定なのとゲームを始めるととんでもないほどの爆音でファンが回転し始めます・・・
同封されていたソフトを使用してOCmodeにすると自分の環境ではブラックアウトからのファン全回転フリーズを頻発し、サイレントモードにしても爆音は変わらず
挙句の果てには公式のドライバ（ソフトウェア）を使用してデフォルトで使用していてもwatman設定をもとに戻しましたとでてプチフリ・・・・設定変えてないのにデフォルトに復元しましたって何を変えたのか・・・

PCをあまりいじったりしない人にはちょっと勧めづらいものだと思います
ファンの回転数とかクロックの調整に他のグラボでなれていたりする人ならコスパは十分だと思います

Reviews.title: Pleased so far.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
Reviews.text:
I made the switch back to AMD this time around after rocking a GTX 970 for many years (and boy did that thing last, I must admit). I'm liking the AMD software now. They've made improvements since my last AMD card (which was back in the early 2000s).

So... the card: It's quite nice. I like the little bit of LED color on it. The card's on the big side, barely making it into my ATX case, and it definitely butts up against the neighboring slot making it useless, but that's fine. I guess I didn't need to add USB C to my motherboard after all.

The card runs cool, even when I'm pushing it. I don't overclock (I'm not an FPS-obsessed twitch gamer) and I'm quite pleased with the quality of graphics and frames I'm getting on games like The Witcher III and GTA V. Older games run great. Skyrim, Fallout 4, all the Batman games-- All deliver well over 60fps on Ultra as long as I turn VSync off (which is fine since AMD has their own version).

This is also a really quiet card. It never gets much louder than my case fans. I can't hear it over the sound of my refrigerator running in the next room (OK, yeah, my fridge is old but it's not THAT loud).

All in all, this was a worthwhile jump up. No, it's not the newest thing out there as of November 2020, but it's a darn good GPU that should take me on into the next few years without trouble.

Five stars.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Canada on October 4, 2020
Reviews.text:
Contrary to what a previous reviewer said, this card certainly performs better than an RX 580 and is comparable to an RX 590 on Windows. On Linux, it is comparable to an RX 580 but that should change once drivers improve. Search for benchmarks online (e.g., Phoronix and FurMark).

Where it really shines through is the power efficiency of the card thanks to the new architecture. This means a cooler and quieter system that won't hit your utility bill as hard.

It's true that this card is limited to 8x PCIe 4.0, but if you have a compatible motherboard then the bandwidth will be the same as a 16x PCIe 3.0 slot. It should also be noted that this card is meant for 1080p gaming so you should not expect to use up all your VRAM like you would at higher resolutions, thus, there should not be much demand placed on the PCIe bus to cause a bottleneck.

I was initially concerned about the aforementioned issue and looked at the RX 580, but after a bit of research and considering that the RX 580 was still much more expensive than the newer gen card, I took a chance with the RX 5500 XT and have been very pleased ever since.

What I did not like was that this card was not shipped in its original box but in thin bubble wrap and placed inside a large Amazon box, allowing it to shift around easily during transit with the potential of damaging its fragile connector. I had to test the card extensively before concluding it was not damaged.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 7, 2020
Reviews.text:
Brought this as an upgrade to a really old GPU after it fell below the minimum requirements to run several game updates. Despite running on an older spec PC there’s a noticeable difference in both display quality and game performance. All games I’ve tried thus far can now run on ultra display settings with no problems other than some performance issues from my PC’s outdated hardware.

The card was a tight fit for my mini itx case as the PSU sits very close to my PCI-E slots but it required only minimum effort to install. The position of the fan works well for my case as nether my PSU or HDDs are positioned where they would otherwise restrict air flow. This may perhaps be a issue with some mini itx cases depending on where they are located and if you have 3.5 inch drives.

The fan also seems to run fairly quietly as well. The power requirements are higher than my previous low spec card but this hasn’t caused an issue since I had the minimum 450w PSU required.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on September 4, 2020
Reviews.text:
Die Installation war problemlos. Ich wagte das, obwohl ich nur ein 350-W-Netzteil habe und eigentlich min. 450 W empfohlen werden. Da die Karte (und der PC insgesamt) relativ sparsam ist (großes Plus!), scheint es aber zu gehen. Ich brauchte nur einen Adapter (2 * Molex auf 8-pin-Stecker). Manche warnen davor, aber es geht.

Leider erzeugt der Lüfter der Karte kaum einen Luftstrom nach außen, verteilt also die Wärme hauptsächlich nur innerhalb des PC-Gehäuses, das dann rundum deutlich warm wird. (Ich hatte das angesichts der Geometrie schon befürchtet.) Ich installierte deswegen noch einen temperaturgeregelten Gehäuselüfter (Arctic F12TC), um die gesamte Elektronik des PCs inkl. Karte zu schonen - das ging problemlos.

Der Lüfter der Karte ist bei Volllast deutlich zu hören, aber das Geräusch ist für mich völlig akzeptabel, auch wenn ich den PC-Schrank wg. besserer Kühlung etwas offen stehen lasse. Bei normalem Windows-Betrieb hört man nichts.

Die Funktion der Karte ist, soweit ich sehen kann, einwandfrei. Insgesamt bin ich recht zufrieden.

Reviews.title: Good card, nightmare drivers
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
Reviews.text:
Did the upgrade so I could continue playing the one game I play. Three days of computer issues. One monitor recognized instead of two but I'm seriously at the point of not caring about the second monitor because at least Windows loads.
All that said, the card itself seems to be working well. It does run hotter than others. I just opened the expansion slot under it to make sure it has plenty of exhaust space.
It does require Nvidia drivers, which are a nightmare and love nothing so much as wrecking a machine running windows 10. Probably the last time I'll buy anything that uses Nvidia, which is sad. They used to be amazing. Hasn't been the case in many years even though I keep giving them another chance.
